—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Given the Government's decision to exclude the motor vehicle industry and the clothing, textile and footwear industries from the general reference to the Industries Assistance Commission, will the Minister say when the Government will take steps to achieve its stated objective of 'a less complicated, lower and stable structure of protection'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Significant progress has been made and is being made in the development of an internationally competitive Australian manufacturing industry with less complicated, lower and more stable levels of protection. In recent years the average nominal rate of assistance to manufacturing has declined from 24 per cent in 1968-69 to 15 per cent in 1980-81, a fall of almost 40 per cent. In effective rate terms, the comparable figures are 36 per cent, declining to 24 per cent. This decline in protection includes the results of decisions to accept in recent years the overwhelming majority of IAC recommendations, in particular the outcome of the tariff review which is now nearing completion. I may go beyond that and say that further reductions are in train as a result of decisions to phase down in stages assistance for more than 20 product groupings.

ANSWER.PARA: Unlike many other countries, Australia relies principally on the tariff for the protection of its industries and that, self-evidently to honourable members on both sides of the House, is a more visible form of protection than that which applies in most markets around the world. If one is taking an overall judgment about the level of protection, it is fair to look at the recent record of import performance. Total imports to this country grew by almost 68 per cent in the three years to 1980-81. Honourable members are aware that a substantial proportion of imports to this country from developing nations do enter at concessional rates. On the latest figures which are available, Australia's per capita level of imports of textiles and apparel is almost twice that of the European Economic Community, two and a half times that of the United States of America and almost five times that of Japan. The level of footwear imports from ASEAN countries is seven times that of the EEC, 11 times that of the United States and 120 times that of Japan. The assertion here is that our record of tariff reduction is creditable by international comparison.

The honourable gentleman quite rightly raises, in the context of making judgments about the level of the tariff, the recent exclusion of the textile, clothing and footwear industries and also the passenger motor vehicle industry. These industries account for only 12 per cent of Australian value added, with the majority of manufacturing being at around 88 per cent. This is still to be reviewed by the IAC. I should qualify that, of course, by referring to the fact that these industries are naturally subject to a wide range of assistance levels from zero to almost 40 per cent.

Finally, I state in reply to the honourable gentleman that the IAC general reference on the lowering of Australian protection will be in report form to the Government I think towards the end of this month or certainly in the early days of March. It will be a matter for the Government to take decisions on the basis of that report, having regard to all of the factors involved. The Australian tariff has been, in the history of this country, one of the most controversial issues which this Parliament has dealt with. It will remain so. That allows for genuine differences of view on both sides of the House and between individual members on both sides of the House.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education and refers to reports circulating around the country, but particularly in New South Wales, that the Commonwealth Government has cut technical and further education funding . Will the Minister advise the House of the exact circumstances and where the Commonwealth stands on funding for TAFE?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to reports, particularly in New South Wales, alleging that the Commonwealth Government has cut funding for technical and further education in 1982. Those reports go on to blame the Commonwealth Government for cut-backs in New South Wales, particularly in the pre- apprenticeship area. The facts are quite different from what is claimed in those reports. In 1982, the Commonwealth has increased its funding in real terms in every category within the TAFE area, be it in the recurrent areas, for which we have a limited responsibility, or in the capital area, in which over the past five or six years we have taken unto ourselves an increased role and an increased responsibility. Indeed, in December 1980 quarter prices the total increase in New South Wales is from $62.4m in 1981 to $71.8m in 1982. The charges that the Commonwealth has reduced funding in real terms in New South Wales and that, as a result, technical college courses have to be cut back are quite inaccurate. If there have been cut-backs in funding and in the provision of courses in New South Wales the responsibility for that rests squarely on the shoulders of the New South Wales Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make a special reference to the pre-apprenticeship area. Last year, with our approval, New South Wales used some of its transition funding to fund pre- apprenticeship courses. The amount sought from the Commonwealth for that purpose in 1981 was $262,000; that is, $262,000 of the New South Wales share of transition money was sought. This year it has sought only $105,000 for this purpose. The New South Wales Government is responsible for determining the priorities in this area. So, on two scores the New South Wales Government is vulnerable: Firstly, if there has been an overall decrease in funding and an overall decrease in the level of the provision of courses in the TAFE area in New South Wales, it is a matter for the New South Wales Government; and, secondly, insofar as pre-apprenticeship is concerned, in the context of transition New South Wales sought to use less of its allocation in that area this year than it did last year. It is that Government that determines the priorities and it is that Government that needs to stand up and accept the responsibility.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for tax cuts to alleviate the increasing burden of taxation on low and middle income earners.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In proposing this matter of public importance for discussion, I seek to bring before this House an issue which is of increasing and acute concern to the great majority of Australians. The crushing increase in the tax burden which has occurred during the six years of the Fraser Government has drastically affected the living standards of all but the very wealthy in Australian society. It is on behalf of all those who are struggling under the weight of the Government's tax policies the low and middle income earners, the unemployed, the pensioners and all socially disadvantaged persons, all those who are appalled at the Government's refusal to alleviate the escalating tax burden, that I call for immediate action to reduce taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: The case for reduced taxes cannot be disputed. this case is summed up under the following points. Firstly, this Government since it came to office-even before then-created legitimate expectations in the minds of people that it would reduce the tax burden. It is an expectation continually confounded by the Government's action in increasing the tax burden. Secondly, low and middle income Australians are now bearing a much heavier burden of direct and indirect taxation than when Labor was last in office. That burden is getting heavier all the time. Thirdly, the burden of increased taxes is being exacerbated by the additional burden of increased interest rates. Fourthly, the state of the economy requires reduced taxation to stimulate economic activity and to take the pressure off interest rates.

The Fraser Government came to power in 1975 with an avalanche of tax cutting rhetoric proclaiming that it would reduce taxes and that it was a low tax party. Time does not allow me to go through all those statements which are well in the minds of all honourable members in this House, having been mentioned many times in the last six years. But it has undoubtedly been a key part of this Government 's rhetoric that it was supposedly the low tax party. Despite these promises, re -run throughout six years in office, this Government has shown by its actions that they are nothing more than a massive deception of the Australian electorate . In no field has the Government's performance failed so dismally to live up to its promise as it has in the field of taxation. Any examination of the facts-any examination whatever-will show that the Government is not a low tax government and that it never has been. On the contrary, the indisputable fact is that the Fraser Government is the highest taxing government in the nation's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —After Labor.

—The honourable member will see what the facts are in a moment in respect of a comparison between Labor and the present Government. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table shows that the increasing tax burden has not been spread evenly across all taxpayers. On the contrary, the burden has been predominantly borne by ordinary wage and salary earners.

SPEECH.PARA: Net pay-as-you-earn receipts-that is, taxes collected from wage and salary earners-have risen from 41.7 per cent of total tax revenue in 1975-76 to 45.7 per cent this year. As a proportion of total wages and salaries and supplements paid, net pay-as-you-earn collections have risen from 41.7 per cent to 45.7 per cent over the same period. At the same time, taxes collected from non-pay-as-you -earn taxpayers-those with incomes from business, property or dividends- have fallen from 13.1 per cent of total tax revenue to 9.5 per cent. From 1975-76 to 1980-81, the last year for which statistics are available, tax payments by pay- as-you-earn taxpayers increased by 101 per cent while total wages and salaries and supplements grew by only 72 per cent. Over the same period tax payments by non-pay-as-you-earn taxpayers grew by 56 per cent while their incomes grew by 94 per cent. Such figures amply demonstrate the effect of Government action in amending the tax scales very much in favour of high income earners and its abysmal failure to control tax avoidance and evasion.

Furthermore, over the same period company tax collections have fallen as a percentage of total tax collections and indirect taxes, which hit hardest at those on the lowest incomes, have increased as a proportion of total taxes. So it is clear that the increasing tax burden is falling squarely on the shoulders of Australian wage and salary earners while companies and those with incomes from professions, business, dividends and interest are, as a group, paying a smaller share of taxation thanks to the Fraser Government's tax policies. If the shares of income tax paid by wage and salary earners, companies and those receiving non-wage incomes were unchanged in this current financial year from those in the last year determined by a Labor Government-1975-76-wage and salary earners would be paying $1,500m less income tax this year, non-wage earners would be paying over $1,300m more income tax this year and companies would be paying $500m more income tax this year. These figures give a clear indication of the direction of this Government's tax priorities.

Whilst it is clear that wage earners have borne the brunt of the increasing tax burden, that burden has not been spread equally amongst them but rather has been loaded on to the vast majority of low and middle income earners. Those with very high incomes, on the other hand, have received substantial tax reductions thanks to this Government's tax policies. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. These tables clearly show that the vast majority of taxpayers are worse off as a result of the Fraser Government's tax policies. In fact, 98 per cent of all taxpayers are paying a higher proportion of their incomes in tax this year than they did during the last year of the Labor Government. All single taxpayers whose incomes have risen in line with average earnings and who earn less than $32,000 this year will pay more of their incomes in tax this year than they did in 1975-76. Furthermore, the increases are much greater for those on the lowest incomes. For example, a person earning $9,500 this year whose income has risen only in line with average weekly earnings since 1975-76-that is, it has gone up by 88 per cent-is paying almost 150 per cent more tax or an extra $7.77 a week than he would be paying if his tax had gone up only as fast as his wages. An income earner on $17,000-around average weekly earnings-will be paying 97 per cent more tax compared with an 88 per cent growth in earnings. Similar results apply to taxpayers with a dependent spouse and children. Taxpayers in this category who earn less than $37,700 a year and whose incomes have risen in line with average weekly earnings will be paying more of their income in tax this year than they did in 1975-76. Only those on very high incomes are better off. A single taxpayer earning $47,000 this year, for example -about three times average earnings-will be $4.53 a week better off while someone earning almost $95,000 will be nearly $50 a week better off.

SPEECH.PARA: These examples clearly show the crushing inequities of the income tax policies pursued by this Government. These inequities have resulted from the Government's failure to fully index taxes against inflation, as it promised in 1975 so strongly to do, and reflects from now on the abandonment of tax indexation altogether which means that the number of taxpayers paying tax at more than 32c in the dollar will rise from a half a million in 1977-78 to about 2.1 million this year. This situation also threatens to take average weekly earnings into the 46c tax bracket next year which will subject all pensioners to tax within a year. Inequities have also resulted from the Government's failure to act decisively against tax avoidance which on the Government's own highly conservative figuring is costing around $1,000m a year or about $4 a week extra tax for every wage and salary earner to make up for the activities of the tax bludgers. The inequities in the income tax system have been compounded by huge increases in petrol tax which has gone from $264m in 1975 to $3,440m this year and sales taxes which are to go up an additional $500m this year alone. In addition most taxpayers are struggling under the burden of higher interest rates which have increased the repayments on an average bank home loan of $30,000 by $ 15 a week over the last two years and they are paying higher costs for health insurance.

In the light of the developments which I have just outlined it is little wonder that the great majority of taxpayers are crying out for tax relief-relief which is thoroughly justified on the basis of equity to the taxpayers. It is also something which is justified on the basis of economic responsibility. The Government argues that to give such tax relief would be economically irresponsible because, firstly, the impending blockage of the sales tax extension to a whole range of new items would reduce its capacity to cut income tax, and secondly, to reduce taxes now would destroy the Budget strategy and put more pressure on interest rates. Let me briefly deal with those two points.

In regard to the first one let me say that I will deal with it more fully in the sales tax debate which is to follow this discussion but I note now that the amount of revenue at stake in respect of sales tax for this financial year as a result of the Bills which are to come before the House this afternoon is only $ 59m. Yet the Government is saying that because it cannot get this $59m that will make it more difficult for it to cut income tax. What a load of nonsense that is . The Government is talking about $59m which represents 0.1 per cent of budgeted tax revenue for this year and it is saying that because it cannot get that revenue it cannot possibly give any tax cuts at present. The full year effect is $330m, and although it is a substantial sum of money in itself, it pales into insignificance when it is compared with the amount of money which this Government will get next year from personal income tax unless there are tax cuts . Using the assumption that was used in this year's Budget, that is that there would be a growth in wages and salaries of 13 1/2 per cent and an employment growth of 2 per cent-those assumptions may be way out but I just use them for the purpose of the exercise-there will be a $5 billion increase in personal income tax revenue in 1982-83. I suspect that the basis of those calculations is quite likely to be out and that the wages and salaries increase will be higher and the employment figure much less, but the overall basis is likely to be reasonably accurate. A $5 billion increase in income tax revenue next year, if this Government does not amend the tax scales, dwarfs the $330m it is talking about in respect of sales tax and shows what utter nonsense it is to argue that tax cuts cannot be given because of some blockage of sales tax legislation in the Senate. I think that puts that one into perspective.

The other point is that the Government says that it must maintain the Budget strategy. It does not seem to realise that the Budget strategy is absolutely in tatters. There is no Budget strategy that is working at present. All of the Government's frenetic attempts to try to maintain the Budget strategy are absurd and totally inappropriate to the needs of the economy at present. The fact is that the Budget strategy is in tatters. This Budget strategy was supposed to be one which would take the pressure off interest rates. Anyone who knows anything about what is happening in the Australian economy at present knows that interest rates are soaring and that, therefore, the basic objective of this Budget, which was to take the pressure off interest rates, has totally failed to be realised. Interest rates are soaring at present.

The Government does not seem to realise that the major reason for that increase in interest rates is that an enormous credit squeeze is occurring. The rate of growth of the money supply is running well below target. There has been a 7.7 per cent annualised rate of growth in the first six months of this year compared to a 10 per cent to 11 per cent target rate of growth. That is a low rate of growth of money supply. That inevitably means a shortage of credit which means that there is likely to be an increase in the price of money-that is, an increase in interest rates. This Government is maintaining a policy of keeping a very low rate of growth of money supply. One of the basic assumptions made in its Budget about the increase of money supply growth has not come to fruition. I will mention why later in another debate. This means that the Government is pursuing a Budget strategy which is helping to bring about a credit squeeze which is forcing up interest rates. In these circumstances it would be far better to have tax cuts which would take the pressure off interest rates by increasing the rate of growth of money supply, stimulating the economy and certainly helping us to recover from the deepening recession which is occurring at present. All of the economic indicators at present are pointing towards deepening recession. Employment growth has virtually ceased. We need a stimulus to the economy and tax cuts are the obvious way in which to do that. This would stimulate the economy directly through expenditures. Also, by increasing money supply growth, there would be less pressure on interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much welcome this matter of public importance because it provides an opportunity to say a few objective and unemotional things about the subject of taxation and to try to put into proper perspective the various calls that are occurring at present all across this country from a large number of quarters for taxation reductions to occur. I want to make one or two fundamental propositions to the House about the relevance and the desirability of personal income tax reductions at present. I assume that the matter of public importance presented by the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) was, in fact, related to the question of personal taxation reductions . Of course, it is eminently popular to call for taxation reduction. One of the easiest, one of the most painless, political clarion calls that anybody can make is to call for personal income tax reductions. Such a call is normally popular. It is normally greeted with acclaim and with support. It is normally regarded as the most eminently reasonable and sensible thing to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the House whether, on all tests, personal tax reductions-that is what we are talking about-at the present time would be desirable. I put it to the House that if we were to reduce taxation we would have to do it either with a commensurate reduction in expenditure or, alternatively, by expanding the size of the Budget deficit. I give the honourable member for Gellibrand credit, and I mean this very sincerely: He believes in expanding the deficit. He is a person who does not worry too much about the size of the deficit. In fact, he believes that big deficits are good economics at the present time. That would be a very interesting proposition to anybody who examined the present state of the economy of the United States of America. It would be an interesting proposition to most responsible economic opinion, which is to the effect that the greatest single cause of high interest rates in Australia at the present time is the impact of a huge domestic Budget deficit upon the level of the United States interest rates. I have no reluctance at all in putting it to the House, and in putting it to the House very sincerely on behalf of the Government, that, in the present budgetary and economic circumstances of Australia, it is not economically desirable on any score to have personal taxation reductions. I welcome this opportunity to say that and to say that without ambiguity and without equivocation on behalf of the Government.

I also make it clear to the House that, at the time when the last Budget was introduced, no promise of any kind, of any shape or form, was made by either the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or me that personal income tax reductions would occur during the current financial year. The honourable member for Gellibrand, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats in another place (Senator Chipp) know that it is completely misleading the Australian people to say that we made any such commitment and that we have in some way gone back on that commitment. What we said at that time , not only in the Budget Speech but also in countless speeches made around Australia after the Budget Speech was made, was that, faced with a choice between a personal tax cut of $500m or $600m at the time of the presentation of the Budget and aiming for a deficit of only $146m, we gave greater priority to the latter option because we believed that to reduce the Budget deficit was the best we could do to take pressure off interest rates.

It is convenient for the honourable member for Gellibrand now to say that interest rate pressures have re-emerged. I put it to him and to the House that, if we had budgeted for a deficit of $1,000m in August last year, interest rates in Australia now would have been very much higher than they are. For the honourable member for Gellibrand to come into this House and suggest that a combination of a Budget deficit then of $1,000m and a $100 billion deficit that now faces the United States people and faces the entire Western economy would not have been disastrous for interest rates in Australia is to completely misunderstand cause and effect in economic matters. What we set out to do at the time of preparing the last Budget was to put a premium on reducing the call of this Government on borrowings throughout our community and thus to reduce the call and the pressure from this Government on the level of interest rates. We believe that was the correct strategy and if we had our time over again we would follow that strategy again.

It is no good pretending that it makes economic or social sense to provide a tax cut today which is to be paid for tomorrow by higher inflation levels and higher interest rates. That is precisely the course of action that is being urged upon us by the honourable member for Gellibrand and, indeed, by others around Australia who make calls for personal income tax reductions without giving proper recognition to what is involved and without displaying a willingness to state how they believe those reductions should be funded; whether they should be funded by a larger deficit or by reductions in expenditure. In the last Budget we decided upon a modest broadening of the sales tax base. It is a very odd situation that legislation designed to broaden the sales tax base, which in fact would have reduced some of the regressive elements that are in the present indirect taxation mix in Australia-I repeat that the sales tax measures we proposed in the last Budget would have made indirect taxation in Australia less regressive-should have been voted against, both in this place and in another place, by the honourable member for Gellibrand and his party, which is supposed to be against regressive taxation.

The fact is that the narrow base of indirect taxation in Australia at the present time is the reason why all the surveys cited by the honourable member for Gellibrand and the Labor Party show indirect tax to be regressive. The more the base of indirect taxation is broadened provided food is excluded, the less regressive the tax becomes. The honourable member for Gellibrand and Senator Chipp of the Australian Democrats ought to recognise that what they are doing in voting against those sales tax measures is rejecting a reduction in the regressive nature of indirect taxation in Australia. They are rejecting not only a sensible change in the taxation mix in Australia but also a reduction in the regressive nature of indirect taxation in Australia. A broadening of the taxation base would bring about a significant reduction in the regressive elements that now exist in indirect taxation.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer will resume his seat. The House will come to order. I remind honourable members that interjections are out of order. I ask them to restrain themselves or I shall be required to deal with them.

—During Question Time, levels of taxation were raised. Of couse, they are fundamental to this debate. I have never disputed the fact that as a straight percentage of gross domestic product, taxation collections now are higher than they were in 1975 and 1976. But I put it to the House and I put it to the Opposition in particular that in making a fair comparison between what governments take out of a community one has to extend one's examination beyond taxation collections and look at what governments borrow from a community which has to be paid back by future generations. I believe that an irresponsible reduction in taxation is only a fraud against future generations because all it does is to load future generations with the responsibility for repaying huge borrowings made by governments.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons why we have interest rate pressures and one of the reasons why domestic capital markets all around the world have very high interest rate pressures are not only the volume of current borrowings that governments have to undertake but also the responsibility of rolling over past debts. When a government runs up a debt, not only has it to borrow the money in the year in which it incurs the debt but also has it to roll that debt over in future years. The Australian capital markets face the enormous problem of rolling over government and semi-government debt which has accumulated over many years. The idea that a deficit is a one-off, once-yearly event, here today and gone tomorrow, is a total misunderstanding, once again, of cause and effect in economic matters. I again put it to the House that those who believe that it is economically or socially responsible to provide for a tax cut today by loading future generations with enormous additional debt burdens, are, in my view, committing a significant fraud against those future generations.

The fact is that, although as a percentage of gross domestic product total taxation collections this financial year will be higher than they were in 1975- 76, if the tax collections in 1975-76 and the domestic Budget deficit then as a proportion of gross domestic product were combined the total would be significantly higher than the total of those two factors will be for 1981-82. That means that this Government is making a lesser call on the resources not only of the present generation but also of future generations in following a fiscally responsible approach to the provision of taxation cuts. The fact is that on any reasonable international standard the overall level of taxation in Australia at present is about five or six percentage points below the average of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

Of course I, as Treasurer in this Government, would love to be in a position to make a big fellow of myself and give a massive taxation cut tomorrow, as would the Prime Minister and every other member on this side of the House. It would be a very popular thing to do and it is very easy to buy that kind of popularity. The question that we have to ask ourselves is how would that be financed. The honourable member for Gellibrand does not have the responsibility of having to provide that answer but at least he has the courage to say that he would do it by going into greater deficit. At least we know where he stands. He is not only a bigger deficit man and a capital gains taxer but also a person who at least is prepared to come into this House and say how those taxation reductions would be financed. If the honourable member for Gellibrand had his way now we would finance taxation reductions by having a bigger Budget deficit. We on this side of the House do not believe that a bigger Budget deficit in the present state of the world economy and in the present state of the Australian economy would do anything other than drive interest rates even higher. For the honourable member for Gellibrand to suggest that it would bring interest rates down because, according to him, we have some kind of credit squeeze at this time is for him once again to misunderstand cause and effect so far as economic affairs are concerned.

One thing this Government has never been prepared to yield in the six years it has been in office is the belief that governments have to discharge some kind of responsibility and on occasions forsake popularity for responsibility so far as economic decision making is concerned. A taxation reduction in the last Budget would have been immensely more popular than the Budget we brought down. A taxation reduction now would be immensely more popular than the stand the Government is taking. But, in the long run, the Australian community would pay for that with a higher level of inflation and a still higher level of interest rates. In blocking in another place a very sensible broadening of the sales tax base the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have put back the cause of sensible reforms to the Australian taxation system. We rely too heavily in this country on personal income tax as a source of revenue. We need a greater reliance on indirect taxation. It is harder to evade and it is a more efficient method of collecting taxes. The Opposition and the Democrats, far from supporting the cause of taxation reform in Australia, have put back the clock of sensible taxation reform for a considerable time.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADELAIDE AIRPORT: UPGRADING FOR INTERNATIONAL SERVICES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Adelaide Airport: Upgrading for International Services.

This proposal is for the upgrading of facilities to enable the operation of direct international air services into and out of Adelaide Airport. This is not presently possible because of the absence of customs, immigration, health and other facilities.

The work will consist of the following elements: A single storey terminal building including facilities for arriving and departing passengers; an apron to accommodate two Boeing 747 aircraft adjacent to the new terminal; a taxiway to connect the new apron to the existing taxiway system; widening of some taxiway fillets to allow regular use by Boeing 747 or other wide-body international jet aircraft; and engineering services, access roads, car parking areas, and improvements to the Airport electrical reticulation system. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $10.9m at January 1982 prices. I table plans of the proposed work.

December 3, 1981
Submission to: Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works
By: Keith C. Bull, Principal, Thebarton Primary School, Rose Street, Mile End, S .A. on behalf of the Children, Teachers and School Council.
I make my submission concerning the introduction of wide-bodied jets and the possible development of West Beach Airport as an international airport on two grounds, namely, noise and safety.

The school is in the direct flight path of planes using West Beach Airport. I understand that commercial jet aeroplanes pass over the school on landing at a little under 200 metres high. Approximately five planes per hour on average, pass over the school between 9 a.m. and 3.30 p.m. which is the lesson time of the school.

I submit that the learning programme is already adversely affected to a significant degree by the continual interruptions created by the jet planes. A teacher speaking to a class of children, a child speaking to a teacher, or another child, has to stop speaking when a jet flies over. It is physically impossible to be heard unless one yells. In 1976 the then Department of Civil Aviation took decibel readings outside the school when jets were flying over on their approach for landing. The officer taking the readings told me that they registered between 105 and 110 decibels.

Every aspect of school life is affected by the jet planes. When we hold an assembly, we use a public address system which has a ten point setting. This setting is placed on eight so that the children who are up to thirty metres from the amplifiers, may hear over the combined traffic noise of Henley Beach and South Roads. I have been told by people who live on the windward side of the school, that the amplification can be heard over one-and-a-half kilometres away. However, when a jet plane flies over the school, all speaking has to stop as the person on the microphone cannot be heard. On occasions, when planes have to circle before landing, the whole assembly is rendered to no avail. Meetings of parents in the school held at any time, are affected in the same way as are telephone calls and all interviews with senior staff and teachers. Lessons held in the school yard are affected in the same way, with even longer pauses being made necessary before the teacher or a child may continue speaking.

How low the planes are may be judged by the fact that on a sunny day, the shadow of a plane going into land, completely covers my office. When a particular set of circumstances coincides, which I do not completely understand, but which I believe has to do with height and angle of turn of the plane and wind velocity, then the windows of the school vibrate. The whole noise situation is intensified when planes are taking off rather than landing.

All of the above places the children of Thebarton Primary School under a severe disadvantage in relation to their learning. When I am told that even more jets and of a possibly noisier kind, are to use the Airport and that the development of the Airport is to be accelerated, then my concern for the children in my charge is heightened to a very considerable degree.

I believe that society as led by Government, must very carefully consider what is done in the name of progress, but which may also be seen as being done in the name of greed, compared with what is being done to one of this nation's greatest and indeed priceless assets, namely, its children.

This need for care of our children is accentuated when one considers the safety aspects of what is proposed. I understand that recommendations for international airports used by such planes as wide-bodied jets include a three kilometre cleared space on the approach, with a further two kilometres of low density use of the land. Thebarton Primary School is within three kilometres of the runway at the Airport. Australia's air safety record, I acknowledge, is excellent. However I understand that West Beach Airport's passenger traffic has doubled in the last decade, and is likely to double again in the next. Presumably, the likelihood of accident is increasing at the same rate. Do we need a jet plane with a full load of passengers on top of a school full of children, before we have the courage to admit that Adelaide's Airport is in the wrong place at its present stage of development, let alone any further development through additional planes or increase in status to international?
Keith C. Bull
Principal.

SPEECH.PARA: Thebarton Primary School is one of seven schools under the flight paths around Adelaide Airport. Jet planes coming into Adelaide Airport pass over that school at less than 200 metres. On average five planes per hour pass over the school during the hours of 9 a.m. and 3.30 p.m. During 1976 the then Department of Civil Aviation took decibel readings outside the school when jets were on their landing approach. Those readings were as high as 105 and 110 decibels. Children and teachers are expected to cope with this sort of thing. I remind honourable members that on average five planes per hour pass over the school. Almost every aspect of school life is being affected by the jets. Mr Bull, in his submission to the Public Works Committee, stated:

I believe that society as led by Government, must very carefully consider what is done in the name of progress, but which may also be seen as being done in the name of greed, compared with what is being done to one of this nation's greatest and indeed priceless assets, namely, its children.

This school is not being subjected just to noise. Some months ago I raised in this House another problem at this school. In addition to noise and pollution from planes, it is subjected to the highest recorded lead levels in Australia. Of course, no Liberal Government has ever shown any concern for the people who happen to live in that area.

The introduction of international flights through the Adelaide Airport would result in greater hardships to those kids and their teachers and to the residents. More important, perhaps, is the question of safety which was raised in the submissions by the headmaster, the residents and myself. I want to mention in this House the problems faced by the district. First of all I want to outline briefly to the House the points that I put to previous hearings of the Public Works Committee. They were as follows:

(1) That the Federal and State Governments declare the site for a new airport with international facilities outside the inner metropolitan area of Adelaide; that a definite commitment is entered into to develop such airport; and that a commencement date be announced.
(2) That provision be made for the noise-proofing of residential homes, hospitals and schools within a certain perimeter-similar to the legislation covering Heathrow Airport in London.
(3) That there be no lifting of the curfew; and that an assurance regarding this be given immediately by the Government.
(4) That only such work as is necessary to maintain proper safety standards should be undertaken until items (1), (2) and (3) are agreed to.

The question of safety has been of very great concern to the residents. On 11 November last authorities under the Department of Transport conducted a mock exercise and it was just that. I contacted the people in charge and asked for details of that exercise, which was called 'Splashdown'. The exercise involved a simulated crash of a Boeing aircraft off the coast and a number of injured passengers being found lying on a wing in the water. Various authorities, such as the fire brigade and the ambulance service, were involved in the exercise. The director of Adelaide Airport was kind enough to give me the debriefing notes . I could not believe my eyes when I read the notes. It was like a script from Dads Army. There was a series of foul-ups in the controlled exercise on 11 November and if they were repeated in a real accident they would spell disaster. The exercise simulated the crash of a Boeing 727 aircraft in the sea two nautical miles off Semaphore with 80 passengers on board. Survivors were picked up before the exercise got under way by vessels which officially were not there. Most of the command problems occurred before the exercise began. Rescue boats could not find the boat ramp. Some survivors got lost. Seriously injured survivors were left behind while others were sent to hospital. Radio communications were so badly affected that urgent messages were delayed. The medical team from Queen Elizabeth Hospital was 40 minutes late because of wrong advice. The Department of Transport command post vehicle could not find the command post and the radio receiver in the vehicle was unusable during the entire exercise. Had the exercise been staged nearer South Glenelg, a more likely spot for such an accident, rescue boats would have been required to be transported to Outer Harbour, some miles away, for launching. This litany of mistakes and foul-ups in a controlled exercise clearly illustrates the magnitude of the disaster we could expect in the event of a real jet aircraft crash in a residential area surrounding Adelaide Airport. To imagine that it just cannot happen is nonsense. The recent crash in Washington of a Boeing 737 into the Potomac River with 81 dead could turn out to be a relatively small disaster against what we would see in Adelaide in the event of a jet aircraft ploughing into the suburbs of Thebarton and Cowandilla.

There have been 13 reported incidents of near-misses at Adelaide Airport between 1979-September 1981, the latest being on 22 September. I think there is plenty of evidence to justify the proposition I have put to the Public Works Committee and to the House that the international airport proposal should be delayed until the Federal and State governments declare where the new airport will be located.

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 1 to 5 (1982) and Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 ( 1982).

The Customs Tariff Proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. Proposals Nos. 1, 2, 3 and 4 formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff changes made by Gazette notice during the last recess. The changes contained in Proposals No. 5 are new and arise from the Government's decisions in relation to the Industries Assistance Commission's reports on polyunsaturated margarine, surge diverters, vibratory road rollers-developing countries preference-and cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools-in respect of razor blades only.

Proposals No. 1, which operate from 2 December 1981, contain changes resulting from the Government's decision on recommendations made by the IAC in its report on primary batteries. The Government decided to provide long term tariff assistance higher than the level recommended by the IAC. This results in a rate of 30 per cent reducing to 25 per cent after three years, rather than the immediate reduction to 20 per cent as recommended by the IAC.

These measures were decided upon in recognition of the defence significance of battery manufacture and the need to provide a suitable competitive environment under which structural change and new investment can occur with minimal employment consequences. These Proposals also contain tariff changes arising from an administrative decision to transfer rates of duty for zinc chromates from tariff item 32.07 to 28.47 and following a classification change by the Customs Co-operation Council.

Proposals No. 2, which operate from 1 January 1982, contain changes resulting from the Government's decision on recommendations made by the IAC in its report on textiles, clothing and footwear. These supersede Proposals No. 8 (1981) introduced into this House on 18 August 1981. These later proposals are necessary to make provision for the additional duty rates that have since been promulgated under the tender quota scheme.

Proposals No. 3, which operate from 12 January 1982, implement the Government's decision on recommendations made by the IAC in its report on certain bags, cases and similar containers. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations in this report. The effect of this decision is to maintain current long term rates of duty but to eliminate the Canadian margins of preference applicable to certain disposable shopping bags falling within 42.02. These shopping bags will continue to be dutiable at rates ranging from 15 per cent to 30 per cent, similar to those applying to plastic bags of 39.07, thus avoiding any possible consumption or production distortions which might otherwise occur.

Proposals No. 4, which operate from 22 January 1982, implement the tariff changes arising from the Government's decision on recommendations made by the IAC in its report on fabricated steel structures. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that steel structures falling within 73.21 be dutiable at a long term rate of 15 per cent. This rate represents a reduction in duty for all goods under reference other than small bore welded pipes and tubes and seamless pipes and tubes, which were previously dutiable at 7.5 per cent.

The IAC recommended that duty reductions be phased in over two years. The Government has accepted that recommendation except in regard to large bore welded pipes and tubes. The duties applicable to these pipes and tubes will be phased in over five years in line with similar goods covered by the Government's decision on the iron and steel industry announced in April 1981. The IAC concluded that its recommendations would not have any adverse economic, social or employment consequences and that improved industry structure, more efficient resource utilisation and some reductions in prices should result. These proposals also contain administrative amendments in relation to: The definition of handicrafts to ensure that goods made of batiked fabrics include only those made up by hand; and item 43 of Schedule 2 which has been amended to restore concessional admission to coated fabrics of 39.01, 39.02 or 39.03.

Proposals No. 5 introduce tariff changes arising from the Government's decisions on recommendations by the IAC in its reports on polyunsaturated margarine, surge diverters, vibratory road rollers, developing countries preference, and cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools, in respect of razor blades only. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations on these goods.

In respect of polyunsaturated margarine, duties will be reduced from 20 per cent to 10 per cent as recommended by the IAC and supported by the industry. A 10 per cent duty will also bring assistance on polyunsaturated margarine into line with that on other margarine products.

In respect of surge diverters suitable for the protection of electricity supply equipment. the duty rate will be 15 per cent. This rate represents an increase from 2 per cent to 15 per cent on such goods having a rating exceeding 5kA. The IAC found that the difference in duty between large and small surge diverters had eroded the local industry's protection. The effective rate of assistance accorded by a tariff rate of 15 per cent is assessed to be slightly below the average for manufacturing industry. In respect of vibratory road rollers and parts therefor the developing countries margin of preference accorded Brazil will be reduced to 10 per cent. The IAC considered that modification rather than withdrawal of the developing countries margin of preference will be sufficient to remove injury to local producers.

In respect of razor blades, import licensing on double edged safety razor blades will be discontinued and the rate of duty will be 10 per cent. Implementation of the decision at this stage has been undertaken due to the imminent termination of import licensing. The IAC advised the Government that the local industry's share of the domestic market could be eroded if duties or other restrictions did not apply. The Government accepted this advice. The changes contained in Proposals No. 5 operate on and from tomorrow. A comprehensive summary setting out the nature of all changes has been prepared and is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.

Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1982) which I have just tabled formally place before Parliament alterations to the excise tariff. The alterations were introduced during the summer recess by Gazette Notice No. 2 (1981) under the authority of Section 160B of the Excise Act. Proposals No. 1 (1982) increases the excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil from $177.53 to $186.26 a kilolitre operating on and from 1 January 1982. This alteration followed determination of new import parity prices by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick). The determination accords with Government policy on import parity pricing for Australian produced crude oil. In addition Proposals No. 1 (1982) decreases the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $37.07 to $20.46 a kilolitre operating on and from 1 January 1982. This change followed a new average wholesale price for naturally occurring LPG being set by the Minister for National Development and Energy in accordance with Government policy. I commend the Proposals to the House.
