SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981 [No. 2]
Second Readings
Debate resumed from 16 February, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills now before the House, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos. 1A to 9A) 1981 (No. 2), are the same Bills as those which came before us twice last year, once when originally introduced and once as the subject of requests from the Senate. In August, as part of the package of the sales tax amendments involving increasing the sales tax on currently taxed items and other measures, the Government brought in a sales tax package of which the legislation now before us is a part. The parts were: First, to increase sales tax on currently taxed items by raising by 2.5 per cent the tax rates at each of the three levels then applying; secondly, by increasing the sales tax on a substantial number of items and reducing it on a few items under the guise of eliminating anomalies and inconsistencies; and, thirdly, extending sales tax at the rate of 2.5 per cent to a whole range of previously untaxed items. With the support of the Australian Democrats in the Senate and against the opposition of the Australian Labor Party, the first two parts of the package have been passed into law. But the third part has been blocked in the Senate through the Democrats supporting in most respects Labor's opposition to those measures. I remind the House that the Bills involve a tax of 2.5 per cent being applied to clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, man- chester, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers, packaging and wrapping materials and tools, in effect, seeking to extend sales tax to all goods not currently subject to tax, except food, medicine and wine.

SPEECH.PARA: The attitude of the Opposition to these Bills is as it was previously. We maintain our view that the extension of sales taxes to such items is highly undesirable and we continue our implacable opposition to them. In this regard we welcome the fact that the Democrats have now found the courage of their convictions and, after months of procrastination and hand wringing, finally have decided to reverse their previous position of opposing the legislation until the last moment and then voting for it. Provided they are able to stick by the latest decision-on their history one could not be completely confident about that-these Bills will be rejected by the Senate and so become one of the bases for a double dissolution. I say on behalf of the Opposition that the Opposition would certainly welcome that. We are not at all fazed by the prospect of fighting an election on policies such as this. There is considerable opposition to these Bills in the electorate, as any honourable member who is in touch with his electorate will know. There has been a large number of petitions on this issue-I presented one yesterday containing about 12,000 signatures-and various other indications of widespread concern at this extension of the sales tax net to the items which I have mentioned.

The Opposition shares that concern for what it considers to be very good reasons. All these reasons have been covered in previous debate on these Bills, but I will briefly indicate again what they are. Firstly, we believe that this represents a repudiation of the pledge of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on behalf of the Government in March last year not to broaden the indirect tax base. After conducting between the time of the last election in October 1980 and March 1981 a review of the possibility of extending indirect taxation, the Treasurer came into the House on 12 March 1981 and said that the Government had decided not to extend indirect taxation because it would be inflationary. Five months later, with inflation at no lower level and the prospects for higher inflation looking worse, he announced in the Budget that the Government would, after all, seek to increase indirect taxes, but not by as much as it had previously considered. He said that, rather than the $3,000m extension of indirect taxation that the Government had been considering, the Government would now seek to increase indirect taxation by only a further $892m-for which we were supposed to be grateful. Nevertheless there was still a complete about face, in our view. The fact that the amount was less than the Government had previously been considering made it no less unwarranted than it had concluded it would be in March of last year. In our view there was a clear repudiation of the pledge to the electorate in regard to the non-broadening of the indirect taxation net. We therefore charge the Government with the repudiation of that pledge.

Secondly, an increase in indirect taxation is inflationary-the Treasurer admitted that in his 12 March statement-and therefore highly undesirable. The fact that the Treasurer announced in the House on 12 March 1981 that the major reason for not extending indirect taxation was that it was inflationary seems to us to be a good reason to view askance the measures which are now before the House, for the very same reason that they are inflationary. Certainly the measures are not inflationary to the same extent as a $3,000m increase in indirect taxation would have been but still, nevertheless, they are notably inflationary. The Treasurer, in his 12 March statement, said that a $500m rise in indirect taxation would add one per cent to the consumer price index. On that basis the rise in sales tax he sought in the last Budget, $892m, would increase the consumer price index by a little under 2 per cent-in fact, 1.8 per cent. That is based on his own figures. Such an increase is no minor affair. Maybe this Government, which says it is concerned to fight inflation first, really does not care about 2 per cent increases in the inflation rate. That seems to be a conflict in the Government's position, but apparently it is its view that a 2 per cent rise is all right. We view it rather differently. We see it as of considerable concern that the inflation rate would be boosted by some 2 per cent by these sales tax measures. The increases in sales tax contained in the last Budget and already imposed-they were passed by the Senate-in conjunction with the health insurance rearrangements have added 1.7 per cent to the December quarter consumer price index and we have now moved back into double digit inflation. We have a much greater expectation within the community of a higher level of inflation. Therefore, there is likely to be an exacerbation of inflationary expectations and activity and the continuance of inflation at higher levels is almost guaranteed.

It seems absurd in the extreme for governments which say it is essential to fight inflation first then to undertake action which is patently inflationary. Health insurance rearrangements in the last Budget added 1.3 per cent to the consumer price index and the sales tax measures, if passed in full as this Government would like, would add another 1.8 per cent to the consumer price index. It would be incredibly absurd for the Government to add 3 per cent to the CPI when it says it is essential to fight inflation first. The whole rationale of this Government's economic policy is supposedly the need to do precisely that . It is just another indication, of which we have had so many in the course of this Government's period in office, that one of the major methods by which it seeks to fight inflation is by increasing prices. One has only to state it in that way to see what absurd policy it is.

The third reason we oppose these measures is that increased sales taxes also represent an extension of regressive taxation, about which the Treasurer had something to say earlier today. I will come to his remarks in a moment. We mean by regressive taxation that taxes fall more heavily on lower income earners than higher income earners, and so the tax burden is shifted more on to those who are least able to pay. I have demonstrated quite clearly in previous debates on these Bills, by reference to work by Mr Neil Warren of the University of New South Wales, that indirect taxation does have this regressive effect. Mr Warren looked at the effects of various taxes on taxpayers in differing income brackets in 1975-76 and demonstrated clearly that indirect taxes bore most heavily on lower income earners by taking a higher percentage of their incomes. A move to more reliance on indirect taxation is therefore a move to a more inequitable tax system and one which we therefore strongly oppose. All that the Government has had to say in regard to this until today is that pensioners and other social security beneficiaries would be fully protected from such taxes by automatic adjustment of their incomes in accordance with movements in the CPI; that is, insofar as the taxes show up in the CPI, there will be an adjustment under the six-monthly policy of pension adjustments in line with movements in the CPI and so pensioners and other social security beneficiaries will be fully protected.

I acknowledge that there is some truth in this but it is by no means clear that pensioners will be fully protected by such pension adjustments because their expenditure is much more likely to be on essentials than that of wage and salary earners generally and may therefore be more affected by these tax increases than would the consumer price index, which is weighted on the consumption pattern of wage and salary households generally. In any case, many pensioners and other beneficiaries receive income apart from their pensions which is unlikely to be adjusted to take account of the increased tax, so it will obviously have some effect on them. More importantly still, the fact that the lower income earners may be partially protected from the tax does not reduce its regressive impact on the rest of the taxpayers. It will still bear much more heavily on lower income households of the non-pension variety than on higher income households and so it is still regressive and therefore to be opposed.

In the debate on the matter of public importance raised earlier today the Treasurer claimed that the extension of the indirect tax base, as is proposed in these Bills, will make indirect taxation as a whole less regressive. That was an interesting line and I wish he had filled it out a bit more. Perhaps he will do so in his reply to this debate. I assume he was saying that, in regard to the current items which are subject to indirect taxation, if we were to extend the indirect tax base to other items and therefore reduce the amount of tax on the current items, we would have a less regressive indirect taxation system. I am not sure about that but I concede that it might well be the case. It assumes that there is to be some shift of the burden from the current indirect tax items to those which are now being taxed. There is no such move. This is a measure in which the Treasurer is increasing taxes on those items which are already subject to sales tax.

Of course over the last few years there have been mammoth increases in things like the crude oil levy. He is not suggesting that there should be any cut in those taxes. He is not cutting other sales taxes. He is not reducing excise on anything else or on the crude oil levy. He is extending the indirect tax base to these other items, imposing a tax on them and saying: 'Whacko, this is making the indirect tax system less regressive'. I just do not see how that is so, unless he is going to make compensating reductions in those other items, which he has patently not done in this Budget. Presumably he has no intention of doing that because he is all in favour of extending the indirect tax base and the proportion of total tax revenue which is raised by indirect taxation.

So we cannot accept the Treasurer's view that what he has done is introduce some marvellous means of increasing progessivity in the tax system. I do not see it that way at all. I believe that what he has done is simply to increase indirect taxation. Extending the tax base is one of the ways in which he has done that. That is a more regressive form of raising tax revenue than are progressive taxes, such as personal income tax.

The fourth reason we oppose these measures is that they will adversely affect the living standards of Australian families. We previously calculated that the sales tax package of increases as introduced in the Budget would cost the average family about $4 a week. That calculation was arrived at by dividing the total revenue expected to be raised by these measures-the $892m-by the population of the country, allowing for the fact that some of the increases would not be passed on to Australian consumers. On the same basis the measures now before the House will cost the average household about $1.50 a week. This may seem a trifling sum to a well-paid Treasurer but on top of all the imposts on living standards arising from increased income tax, increased interest rates and the sales tax increases that have already occurred, this further impost on family living standards is of real importance.

People are concerned about it. They are concerned about another $1.50 a week that they will have to pay out in taxes in one form or another. This is made more important by the Government's refusal to abide by the undertaking it has given on many occasions, that is, that if the Government were to increase indirect taxation it would make compensating reductions to personal income tax. Where are they? The Treasurer has said today as emphatically as he possibly could that no personal income tax reductions were coming in the near future. So we have the increase in indirect taxes and there is no suggestion of any compensating personal income tax cuts. The Treasurer has ruled that out absolutely and completely. We have a situation in which family living standards will be affected-if these measures are passed by the Senate-by this increase in sales tax which is now before us. This increase would not be offset in any way by reduced personal income taxes.

These are the main reasons we have given for opposing these tax increases. Of course, there have been other reasons, related in part to the inherent undesirability of taxing particular items in the group which are to be taxed, such as books. The tax on books has been described as a tax on knowledge. Rather than pursue those individual items now I wish to review the principal arguments used by the Government for wanting these sales tax increases. The first one is that a shift to more reliance on indirect taxation is desirable because Australia places greater reliance on personal income tax than do other comparable countries. This is something on which the Treasurer has placed considerable reliance. This argument seems to me to ignore the fact that although Australia does raise a higher percentage of its tax from personal income tax than is the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average-I certainly acknowledge that-it also raises a higher proportion of tax from indirect taxes than is the OECD average. The Treasurer is making certain signs and I understand what he is saying.

The fact is that a comparison of our indirect taxes with the OECD average shows that not only do we have a higher proportion of our total tax revenue coming from personal income tax but also we have a higher proportion than the OECD average coming from indirect taxation. I think the Treasurer is being naive in the extreme in saying: 'Look, because we have a higher proportion of our total tax revenue coming from personal income tax we have to have increased indirect taxation'. The fact is that it is already above the average of comparable countries. If we look at the figures which come from the latest OECD revenue statistics we find that the OECD average of personal income tax is 32.56 per cent as against the Australian average of 44.32 per cent. If we add social security contributions by employees the OECD average moves up to 39.89 per cent of revenue coming from personal income tax and employees' social security contributions, which is still below Australia's figure of 44.32 per cent.

Let us look at indirect taxes. The OECD average is 29.35 per cent of revenue coming from indirect taxes. The Australian average is 31.71 per cent. Where is the need to increase indirect taxes? I suggest that the Treasurer should look at a third area where the comparisons with the OECD are very revealing indeed. If we look at the combined impact of company tax, employer social security contributions and payroll tax, see what the percentage is for the OECD and compare that with Australia, we see a startling difference indeed. These are all taxes paid by companies. The OECD average is 24.39 per cent of total tax revenue coming from those scources. In Australia the average is 15.41 per cent, about 9 per cent less. That seems to me to be something which is of considerable interest in that if one is going to say, 'Look, we need to rearrange our tax structure because it is out of line with that of other countries', one should have some regard to the taxes being paid by companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you put out a payroll tax?
—No, I will come to some of that in a moment.
—Come to payroll tax. That would help employment a lot!

—I will come to some of that in a moment. I believe the Treasurer is way out of line in using these OECD comparisons. He has misused them completely and continously by talking about personal income tax and ignoring the fact that in the area of indirect taxes we are above the OECD average. There is no argument for saying that on the basis of international comparisons we need to extend indirect taxation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, one other argument that has been used by the Government is that an increase in the percentage of tax raised by indirect taxes is desirable because of the intrinsic merits of gathering taxes in this form. The Treasurer used some of this argument again today during the discussion of the matter of public importance. He said that it is easier to collect, that it is more difficult to avoid and that there is less distincentive to personal and business effort. I agree that it probably is easier to collect but I do not find that a compelling argument in itself for moving to more and more indirect taxation. He says that it is more difficult to avoid. This is also probably true but it is not impossible to avoid indirect taxes. There have been tax avoidance schemes designed to minimise or completely eliminate sales tax payments for persons concerned.

Also, in our view, it is a complete copout to say that preventing the avoidance of income tax is too difficult and that, therefore, we will move to a form of indirect taxation. This is just capitulation to high income earners who are avoiding taxes. It puts the burden more and more on lower income earners because of a lack of resolve to really crack down hard on high income tax avoiders, which seems to us to be a far more desirable way to go about raising more revenue, if that is what the Government wants to do. Of course, we have made many recommendations to the Treasurer as to what he should do in that regard.

Thirdly, in this category the Treasurer talked about less disincentive coming from indirect taxation. Where is his proof that income tax at any level-perhaps apart from extreme levels of around 100 per cent, but at rates generally levied by other countries or this country-is reducing work effort? Where is the evidence for that? There is no evidence. I know of no study undertaken by any economist or econometricians which shows any relationship between tax levels and work effort. Recently a study was done by the OECD which came to the conclusion that there was just no discernible relationship between work effort and tax levels. I believe all this argument which is being put forward about the disincentive effect of personal income tax is totally based on hunch rather than on any sound investigation of reality. People faced with high marginal personal income tax may feel that they have to work harder to achieve a certain after-tax income rather than be dissuaded from work effort. Certainly, the studies do not show that it comes down strongly either way. So I dismiss this disincentive argument as a reason to move towards indirect taxation as one which has no basis in any scientific study and is simply based on hunch and prejudice.

Fourthly, the Government says that increases in indirect taxation are needed to enable a reduction in personal income tax to take place. I have already dealt with this argument to some degree in debating the matter of public importance today. It assumes that other tax measures cannot be taken. Of course, Labor has referred to other tax measures which should be taken. We have said that a resources rent tax should be introduced, that we should have a tougher approach to tax avoidance and that we should abolish the investment allowance, just to name a few examples. These would be far more equitable ways to raise revenue, if needed, by way of income tax. To say that indirect tax rises are needed to fund income tax cuts is to promise nothing, in effect, to taxpayers as a whole. What the Government is saying is, 'We will take more money off you in this less discernible way'-which of course is one reason the Government likes it-'by putting up the price of all the things you buy, and then we will make big fellows of ourselves around election time by giving you tax cuts'. In the end the taxpayer will be no better off-assuming eventually he gets the personal income tax cuts referred to. But what an absurd suggestion it is that one has to increase indirect taxes in order to provide income tax cuts. That leaves taxpayers as a whole no better off. What you have in the end is a less equitable tax system, one in which low income earners are paying a higher proportion of total taxes.

To argue further that indirect taxes are needed now to provide income cuts later seems to me to be absurd. The tax revenue at stake in this year from these proposed increases amounts to $59m, and in a full year $330m. That may be compared with the $5 billion, approximately, of personal income tax revenue that will be gathered next year if no change in the income tax rate scales is made. That is based on the same assumptions about employment and wage growth as were made in preparing this year's Budget. So roughly speaking, we can see that there is going to be a $5 billion increase in personal income tax revenue to the Government, if the tax scales are not adjusted. Thus, to argue that the Government needs the sales tax revenue which would result from the Bills before us in order to fund personal income tax cuts is an utter absurdity.

Another reason given is that sales tax increases are needed, as part of the Budget strategy, to take the pressure off interest rates. This argument shows that the Government is a victim of its own propaganda. It still believes that its actions are taking the pressure off interest rates, but in fact they are putting more pressure on those rates, as is shown by what is happening to them at present in the market. This is because of the slow rate of growth of the money supply, brought about by the non-occurrence of money supply growth from external sources.

Months and months ago-in October of last year-when the Parliament was in session, the Treasurer rubbished the idea that any shortfall in money supply growth was likely because of the non-arrival of money supply growth from external sources-that is, by way of surplus on private sector foreign exchange transactions. He said that that was of no real concern. It is of concern. Half of the year has gone by. It is quite clear that there has been little or no impetus to money supply growth, such as the Government budgeted for, from external sources. It expected almost half of the money supply growth to come from that source. It has not arrived, and there is no real likelihood that it is going to, because the balance of payments current account deficit is much higher than the Government expected and there is not likely to be any great turnround in it in the next six months.

In those circumstances, because the Government is sticking by its Budget strategy and is maintaining its monetary policy in much the same way as presumably it would have done if that money had come into the country, we have been developing a credit squeeze of no mean proportions and a shortage of money, with a money supply growth of 7.7 per cent, on an annualised basis in the first six months of the year, compared with the Budget target rate of 10 to 11 per cent. That is one hell of a shortfall. The 10 to 11 per cent figure could certainly be argued as being too tight anyway, but when it is 7.7 per cent, with inflation running at 11 per cent, how are we to have enough funds around to provide for growth in the economy. We have not got it. As a result, we have this shortage of funds, this pressure on interest rates, and the Treasurer standing here saying, 'This policy is the best one that you can have to take the pressure off interest rates'. Quite to the contrary, it is putting the pressure on interest rates. What he should be doing in the present situation, instead of standing by his Budget strategy, is abandoning it because it is based on assumptions that certain things will happen which have not happened and which are not going to happen. I refer in particular to external money supply growth. As a result of what is happening in regard to the availability of credit and interest rates his strategy is turning into one which is pushing this country deeper and deeper into recession. The Government should be abandoning that policy and introducing other policies which would stimulate the economy, increase the rate of money supply growth, enable us to get out of the deepening recession into which we are now headed and stop the frightening escalation of interest rates which is of enormous concern to every Australian.

The Treasurer would have us believe that any such tax cuts would increase the pressure on interest rates because they need to be funded by increased Government borrowing. The point that I have made-I make it again-is that it would not be necessary at present, because of the slow rate of growth of the money supply, to fund them by increased borrowing. An increased deficit at this stage would be, to some degree, thoroughly responsible because it would be within responsible monetary aggregates. We are not suggesting that the rate of growth of the money supply is irrelevant. Of course, it is important but what we do say is that it is absurd to be pursuing a policy which represents a large reason for the slow rate of growth of the money supply and one which is creating such interest rate pressure.

The sixth reason that the Government has produced for Australians accepting sales tax increases-it is one which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in particular has been fond of using-is that, supposedly, there has been a large increase in real disposable incomes of wage and salary earners and therefore they can afford to pay these increases, which are said to be necessary to the Government's Budget strategy.

In fact, the figures that have been used by the Prime Minister in respect of this supposed large increase in real disposable income are utterly false and misleading. I believe they do him no credit, nor do they do any credit to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), who used them yesterday. What they are saying is that there has been, on an annualised basis, an increase in real average weekly earnings of $700 in the two years between the September quarter of 1979 and the September quarter of 1981. But that takes no account of the fact that, between September 1975 and September 1979, there was a $200 decline, so that real wages fell over that period. It takes no account of the fact that there was a very significant increase in the tax burden between September 1979 and September 1981. When you take account of that increase in the tax burden you find that there is a very substantial change in the situation, that for some taxpayers there has been no increase at all in real diposable income after tax between September 1975 and September 1981. That is to say, the real disposable income of a person on average weekly earnings, with dependent spouse and two children, was less in September of 1981 than it was in September 1975.

Of course, these examples take no account of the increase in interest rates, which is of great concern to all Australians. Therefore, the suggestion that there has been a large increase in disposable incomes which can enable Australians to afford easily these increased sales taxes represents an absolute misleading of the Australian public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills are before us today with the now stated and changed attitude of the Australian Democrats threatening their passage through another place. To put it mildly, I am surprised at the decision of the Australian Democrats to reject these money Bills. Unquestionably, their explanation has a taint of political expediency about it. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has stressed repeatedly that the proposed sales tax changes are an integral part of the Budget and central to achieving its objectives and that, as such, they ought not to be rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Bills is to establish a new sales tax regime under which food , medicine and wine remain exempt. Items that are broadly classified as necessities, which previously were exempt, will be taxed at 2 1/2 per cent. When the proposals were introduced by way of the Budget they were accompanied by measures to increase existing sales taxes by 2 1/2 per cent and to remove certain anomalies. Significant exemptions would cause a substantial drop in revenue. Taken together they were estimated to increase revenue by $892m in a full year. As the Treasurer acknowledged, these changes represented a broadening of the tax base and a change in the tax mix. This, as the facts show, is desirable. Indeed last year I, like others, argued the Government's case for a broadening of the tax base. However, this was done on the clear understanding that any move towards increased reliance on indirect taxation would be accompanied by offsetting reductions in personal income tax. I recall, as others have done, the Treasurer's words to the House on 12 March last year after the taxation review was completed. He said:

Throughout its considerations of this issue, the Government remained firmly of the view that if a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation were to occur, it should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax .
In the same statement the Treasurer said that the purpose of the review was to:

assess the desirability of altering the mix or combination of taxes, to the extent possible, in the context of reducing the overall burden of taxation; it was not to bring about and increase in the overall tax burden.

The Government has defended the increased sales taxes on the grounds that they enhance the potential for personal income tax reduction 'in future years' as economic and budgetary conditions permit. Of course, the Government must always be guided by economic prudence but one can only speculate as to when circumstances might allow for such income tax cuts. We are now told 'not before this year's Budget'. The Treasurer has said that he gave no promise on personal income tax in his earlier speech but he did say that it was the Government's firm view that income tax cuts should accompany a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation. We have had increased sales taxes but still await personal income tax relief.

I want to express my regret now that the action by the Senate in first deferring, and now by the Australian Democrats threatening to reject, these new Bills has made it harder for the Government to reduce personal income tax. However, this does not reduce the need for such relief. In recent years the burden of personal income tax has grown alarmingly, especially during the 1970s. Despite the significant contribution of the oil levy, now around 10 per cent of tax revenue, personal income tax represents 55 per cent of total tax revenues, down only slightly from the peak of 57 per cent in 1977-78. Of more concern is the fact that gross pay-as-you-earn tax is estimated to be 49.4 per cent of total tax revenue in 1981-82, almost equal to the peak in 1976-77, while net PAYE will be 45.7 per cent, an all-time high. I repeat: This is despite the contribution of over $3 billion from the oil levy.

I do not overlook the effect that the change to family allowances has had on net personal income tax revenue. Between 1971-72 and 1980-81 net income tax on individuals grew at an annual rate of 19 per cent. Net PAYE tax grew at the same rate compared with growth in other income taxes of 16 per cent. By contrast, sales tax grew by 13 per cent a year, company tax by 14 per cent and total taxes by 17 per cent. Income taxes on individuals accounted for 52.5 per cent of the total increase in receipts, 44 per cent of this coming from those paying PAYE tax.

In the last six years the Government has made certain reforms in the taxation field. These have been spelt out by the Treasurer and important among them was the introduction for a time of tax indexation, one of the fundamental elements of Liberal Party policy in recent years. Yet full indexation applied only in 1976-77 and 1977-78 and half indexation of the standard rate scale applied in 1978-79 and 1980-81. Now it has been abandoned altogether. I am aware of the Government's reasons for not maintaining automatic adjustments but the Government has not, so far as I am aware, publicly abandoned its commitment to adjust tax rates for the effects of inflation and reduce the overall burden of taxation.

Inflation and the tax system continue to take their toll on individual incomes. The Budget estimated that average wages would increase by approximately 13 per cent in 1981-82 although it now looks as though the increase will be greater. The Government's revenue from PAYE tax was expected to increase by 22 per cent, and I understand from the Department of Finance figures that this is running approximately on target. Average weekly earnings are approaching the level at which they will no longer incur the standard tax rate. Despite what the Opposition claims, there is scope for increasing reliance on indirect taxation so long as it is offset by personal income tax cuts, especially for low income families.

Whilst I do not set much store by international comparisons, Australia tends to rely more on personal income tax and less on indirect taxation as a source of revenue than most other countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Moreover, Australia relies heavily on specific taxes on a few items, namely, alcohol, tobacco, crude oil, petroleum products and motor vehicles, which in 1980-81 accounted for over 80 per cent of the total taxes on goods and services. In 1975 the Asprey Taxation Review Committee recommended greater emphasis on indirect taxes. As I have said previously, high income taxes stifle incentive and encourage tax avoidance and tax evasion. They also encourage speculative investment for capital gain and can stimulate wage demands . In the last year the average family has been squeezed on all sides-higher interest rates, higher government charges, dearer health insurance, dearer petrol and now higher taxes, both direct and indirect. They will have a direct impact on the willingness of the trade union movement to show restraint in its wage claims.

I listened carefully to what the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) had to say, particularly about regressiveness. The Australian Labor Party has made rather exaggerated claims about the regressive nature of indirect taxes, arguing that they fall most heavily on low to middle income earners. The Australian Democrats have agonised about a tax on so-called necessities. It is true that the low to middle income group spends rather more of its total income than do high income earners-that ought to be axiomatic-and more of its expenditure is devoted to basic items. On the other hand, expenditure tax is much more difficult to avoid than direct income tax and the amount paid will vary with expenditure patterns both within and among income groups. The Labor Party has conceded that, for the rich, paying income tax has become optional, making the present system inequitable. With the indirect taxes, greater discretion remains with the individual as to how his or her income is spent and, indeed, how the tax is paid. This is a very important point. Governments have to allow families to have maximum choice in deciding how to dispose of their incomes. Of course, this is contrary to Labor Party views about the role of government. The proposed tax on so-called necessities is very low while food remains exempt, and there is a degree of progression in the sales tax structure.

Let us recall the record of the Labor Party in government. All taxes increased. The Hayden Budget, of which the Opposition is so proud, significantly increased indirect taxes and revenue from sales taxes went up by 22 per cent and excise duties by around 20 per cent. In other words, the Labor Party taxed beer and cigarettes-a pretty good way of hitting the poor. Similarly, we do not hear the Opposition calling for cuts in the tariff duty on clothing or footwear. According to the Industries Assistance Commission, the average nominal rate of assistance for clothing and footwear in 1977-78 was 64 per cent. The average effective rate of assistance was 149 per cent. A 2 1/2 per cent sales tax pales into insignificance. The total assistance afforded to the clothing and footwear industries in 1977-78 was equivalent to a tax on consumers of $980m or over $200 per household. It will have increased significantly since then and, by contrast, the Democrats now say they will save families $1.30 a week.
In order to reduce reliance on specific indirect taxes-the excises and the oil levy, which will show little growth in the future-it is necessary to cast broadly the sales tax net.

The real issue in this debate is not whether so-called necessities are taxed but whether there are any offsetting personal income tax cuts or other measures of relief particularly for low income earners. I note that those in receipt of most pensions and benefits will be automatically compensated through indexation. The new sales taxes, together with the increases passed in September, would have raised around $900m in a full year-a significant addition to revenue. This would have to have been made up in other ways if the sales tax changes had not been adopted in their entirety. Already delay of these Bills has cost the Government approximately $80m and would cost about $300m in a full year.

Of course, for the Labor Party this may not be a concern. It is expert in running deficits; the community suffered inflation to prove it. The Opposition has made some suggestions for increasing revenue, for example, a resources rent tax which it would impose on mining companies making, what it seems to be, excessive profits. One wonders how much revenue a Labor government would have collected this year. It would terminate the investment allowance but, of course, this would have no immediate effect on revenue. The Opposition would abolish tax avoidance-a worthy objective-though its record is rather less impressive. The fact is that in opposing the sales tax increases the Opposition has not shown where it would raise the additional revenue. Yet, as I recall, the whole thrust of the speech on the Budget made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) was to increase Commonwealth Government expenditure-a typical example of the Labor Party's approach to economic management.

One option is to increase government borrowing. However, the Government has quite correctly set aside this option because it would further aggravate the pressure on interest rates. While I applaud the Government's continuing commitment to restraint one option which also needs to be considered and which I raised in my comment on the Budget is the reduction of Government expenditure and greater concentration on those in genuine need. There is no doubt that sales tax increases add to the consumer price index although estimates vary as to the size of the increase we can expect. This highlights a problem referred to by the Treasurer in his speech in March 1981 when he said that to achieve a significant reduction in personal income tax would require offsetting sales tax increases that would substantially add to inflation. Indeed, the reason for the Government 's decision earlier in the year not to increase indirect taxes was, as the Treasurer said:
. . . its concern at the impact on inflation and inflationary expectations of any significant shift towards greater reliance on indirect taxation.

One concludes that the only way significant income tax cuts can be achieved without severe effects on the CPI due to increased reliance on sales tax is through even greater restraint in government expenditure. That means concentrating assistance to those who genuinely need it and a willingness by less needy groups to accept lower levels of government benefits and services.

In conclusion, I have supported the sales tax Bills because they are an integral part of the Budget and the longer they are delayed the more confusion will be caused to business and the community generally. I have supported them also because they represent a move towards broadening the tax base. Unfortunately the increases in indirect tax have not been accompanied by a significant reduction in personal income tax as people had been led to expect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock ), I will try to restrict my remarks to the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) before the House and to sales tax in general. In fact, one would wonder from the remarks made by the honourable member for Kooyong whether he was speaking in favour of the Government or whether he was speaking against the Government measures. The Bills presently before us are similar to those introduced on two occasions last year. They specifically impose tax at 2 1/2 per cent on a range of items which were previously exempt from sales tax. Included in this category are clothing, footwear, drapery, soft furnishings, manchester, building materials, books, magazines, newspapers et cetea.

SPEECH.PARA: The other sales tax measures introduced last year and which have now become law have already affected people throughout Australia and have already added to the nation's increasing inflation. Briefly looking at those measures a little closer we shall see that the schedules increased by 2 1/2 percentage points included such items as radio and television receivers, record players, cameras, films, watches, jewellery and cosmetics which went from 27 1/2 per cent tax to 30 per cent for schedule 2. Schedule 3 covered goods increased from 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent and includes household furniture, appliances such as refrigerators, washing machines and a range of household goods. Schedules 4 and 5 covered goods increased from 15 per cent to 17 1/2 per cent and covers motor cars, commercial vehicles, boats, confectionary, stationery, computers, soft drinks, potable spirits and imported wines and beers.

The effect of the total sales tax measures as outlined by the Government was to enable the Government to raise some $892m in a full year. The sales tax measures on goods already subject to tax which came into effect on 19 August 1981 and raising $550m in a full year can now be coupled with the tax on these other items originally scheduled to come into effect from 1 January. However, because of the actions taken by the Senate late last year the Treasurer was forced to announce on 28 October that the tax on these items would not now come into effect until 29 March this year and this would mean a subsequent loss of revenue of some $79m. The latest information to hand would perhaps suggest that these latter measures will be rejected by those discerning members of the other place across Kings Hall.

From the time when the sales tax proposals were introduced into this House in August, there has been a steady stream of opposition to them in this House, in the Senate and throughout the Australian community. Why has this been so? The answer is quite simple. It is because these sales tax proposals will cause further inequity in the Australian community. These sales tax measures, particularly the extension of sales tax into the necessities of life such as clothing, footwear, home building materials, educational books, household furniture and appliances, will have an overbearing impact on the cost of living and millions of ordinary Australian families and low income earners. The whole of year costs of $330m on those items subject to the current legislation being debated at present give a breakdown of $27.5m on newspapers, magazines and books , $7m on wrapping material, waxed paper and greaseproof paper, $96m for building materials for private dwellings and $104m for clothing and footwear.

The sales tax measures introduced under the guise of further spreading the tax burden are totally iniquitous and unnecessary and the Australian community has at last begun to realise the impact that these measures will have on the cost of living. As an indirect tax, the sales tax increases already imposed from 19 August have fallen heaviest on those in the lower income bracket. The increases proposed for those items on which tax will be imposed from 29 March will bite even more harshly into the incomes of families and low income earners. Of course , what we have seen is yet another one of the Government's broken promises. The Treasurer stated on 12 March last year, when he announced the Government's decision not to proceed with the introduction of a new broadly based indirect tax, that the Government was anxious to 'minimise the inflationary consequences of collecting additional revenue' and that it did not wish to 'move towards greater reliance on indirect tax without providing a noticeable offset in personal tax reductions'. Quite contrary to these promises, taxpayers have now been slugged with an extra $562m increase in sales tax in a full year which, as we have seen, has already added to the inflation rate.

Increased sales taxes are completely reprehensible as they hit hardest at those on the lowest incomes. Many articles essential to the family budget have been hit. Sales tax on furniture, floor coverings, whitegoods, crockery and bedding has been doubled from 2 1/2 per cent to 5 per cent. Not only will increased interest rates mean a higher cost of buying one's home but also it will now be even more expensive to furnish it and live in it. Clothing, building materials, shoes, books and newspapers will now be subject to a new 2 1/2 per cent tax, with the tax on school books costing parents an extra $6m a year. The increased family allowance for large families will be eaten up quickly by the higher cost of keeping children in clothes and shoes.

The Housing Industry Association has estimated that the tax on building materials is likely to add $1,000 to the cost of building and furnishing a new home. The National Roads and Motorists Association has calculated that the cost of a new six-cylinder Holden Commodore has risen by $178 and of a four-cylinder Datsun by $150. Even the oil to run the car will cost 17 1/2 per cent more. The net effect on the family budget of all these increases has been a cost increase of over $4 a week. This will have a disastrous impact on family living standards , which have already been battered by rising interest rates and more expensive health costs since the last election. Added to the increase in income tax of over $11 a week for a family with a breadwinner on average weekly earnings, it means a massive tax increase of over $15 a week.

A number of Government members stated in the August and October debates on similar Bills that the increases would not have very much impact on low income earners. This was supposed to indicate that, as a result of the spending patterns of various levels of income earners, the burden of sales tax would fall more heavily on high income earners. This is nonsense, contrary to the facts and quite contrary to informed economic opinion. The Taxation Review Committee's report of 1975 under the chairmanship of Mr Justice K. Asprey showed quite clearly that taxation is quite sharply regressive at the lower end of the household income scale, nearly proportional in a wide middle band and progressive only at higher levels. The reason given was that indirect taxes are chiefly responsible for this occurrence. INTERJECT.PARA: One might ask why the Government is persisting with the sales tax legislation when there is such opposition from the community at large. The amount of taxation that would be lost if these measures were not to be proceeded with is small and is more than offset by the large increase in personal taxes payable to the Government through the effects of its inflationary actions on the economy. The only reason for the Government wishing to persist with these measures is obviously its desire to increase its income so that it will be in a better position to offer tax cuts just prior to the next election. It obviously hopes that the community's view of the Government's image will be suddenly changed from that of a money-grabbing Scrooge to that of a benevolent Father Christmas. The Government's efforts in this regard will be seen through by the Australian community as a shabby trick and the Government will be taught a salutary lesson by the voters of this country who have not forgotten the broken promises and actions of deception by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and members of this Government.

The insistence of the Government in going ahead with these measures also means, in my opinion, that it intends progressively to increase sales taxes on a greater range of items than those covered by the present legislation. It is obviously part of a long term plan to widen the tax base to incorporate a greater proportion of indirect taxation. This, of course, is in line with the recommendations of the Asprey report of January 1975 and the Department of the Treasury Taxation Paper No. 5 of October 1974, which recommended that governments should impose sales taxes on a wider range of items including food, clothing and services. The Asprey report stated that 60 per cent of personal consumption expenditure, including virtually all that on food, clothing and services, is not directly subject to tax. Because of the Government's decision to tax clothing, the recommendations of the paper must now assume greater significance as it is obvious that the Government will proceed in the future to implement the remainder of the recommendations by imposing a tax on food and services. To get some idea of the effect that taxes on food and services would have on the community we have only to realise that personal consumption expenditure on food is almost double that on the clothing and manchester area and that service expenditure is similar to expenditure in the clothing area. What this means, therefore, is that a tax on food and services would impose a further cost of at least $350m a year on Australian families.

In an effort to give some justification for increasing indirect taxes the Treasurer and other Government speakers have stated that there is a basic need in Australia to raise the level of taxation coming from indirect taxes because it is relatively low compared with that in other countries. This, of course, is not true, as was outlined by my colleague the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) only a few moments ago. The fact is, of course, that the proportion of indirect taxes raised in Australia is above the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development average and above the proportion raised by many countries, including Canada, Japan, Germany, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States of America which, incidentally, raises only half the proportion that we raise from indirect taxes.

The measures proposed by the Government are nothing more than a confidence trick on the Australian community, nothing more than a money-grabbing exercise to swell the Government's coffers at the expense of the lower income groups in Australia. The Opposition will continue to oppose this legislation. It is to be hoped that the Australian Democrats will show a greater degree of intestinal fortitude when these Bills are debated shortly in the Senate by rejecting the proposed sales tax increases in their entirety because of the iniquitous effects such increases will have on the Australian community.

The Budget has served above everything else to bring about a change in the climate of interest rates.
He went on to say:
If we had the opportunity to retrace our steps--
which, I would point out to him, of course the Government has now got thanks to a hostile Senate-

That was not the case in 1974 and the latter days of the Labor Party Government. That philosophy did not work at that time and it would not work if reintroduced now. From what we can understand from the Labor Party, it has a half-baked wealth tax cum capital gains tax policy. Perhaps the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), who is sitting at the table, might be able to inform us just where things stand with the capital gains tax issue or the wealth tax issue and what sort of additional taxes the Labor Party proposes imposing on the Australian people. We know that, under a Labor government, there would be an increase in taxes connected with medical costs, underestimated by 50 per cent. Also, an additional tax has been talked about.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with direct tax-I think this is acknowledged by all members in the House-is that it denies people the incentive to earn additional funds, be it by working overtime in a factory or by seeking to advance themselves by way of study or courses which will improve their rewards in their place of work. The more people earn the more taxes they pay. Pay-as-you-earn taxpayers have no capacity to do anything but pay on a regular weekly basis that which is required by the Australian Taxation Office. They do not have avenues of minimising tax that may be available in other areas within the economy.

The wage claims of the past few months are in part attributable to the concern that wage earners have about taxation. Of course, the avoidance of direct taxation is very difficult to detect, but this Government has spared no effort in endeavouring to expose tax avoidance schemes and to have them closed by way of effective legislation and providing the Commissioner of Taxation with discretionary powers to close loopholes in the Income Tax Assessment Act. We have, too, insidious problems within the direct tax economy. I refer to the problems that are caused by a cash economy, by the small subterranean cash payments that lead to a huge amount of tax avoidance. It is understandable that on a day to day basis people enter into cash transactions, but in so doing they avoid their responsibility to the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like the Gallagher trust.

—Yes. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs reminds me that such occurrences have been noted in the past few days in connection with certain royal commission inquiries. Indirect taxes have the advantage that the user pays . The big spender is the one who pays the most tax. Tax avoidance in an indirect tax system is almost impossible and, of course, with indirect taxes those people who are involved in a cash economy contribute at least something towards the costs of their fellow man, be it for defence or social security purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has the objective of sound economic management. I think that the introduction of a selective and modest indirect taxation system in the last Budget extends by some $800m the Government's capacity to raise funds by way of indirect taxes. The expedient decision made in the past day or two by the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party will reduce by $330m that amount of money planned in the Budget. That is a dramatic reduction in the $800m planned in the Budget. In fact, the delays to date in having indirect taxation legislation approved by both Houses has cost revenue $79m, which is more than the amount allocated to the Home Savings Grants Scheme. Those people who are operating in the sales tax area should think about their fellow Australians. They should consider how those funds might have been used and what the options would have been had the Government had an opportunity to use those funds which it has not been able to collect. As much as $79m has been lost due to delays. The Home Savings Grants Scheme costs annually $74m.

The legislation we are looking at tonight covers basically new areas of sales tax, including imposing sales tax on newspapers, books, wrappings, building materials, clothing and footwear. We are told that the decision made by the Senate, led by the Democrats, will save a family something like $1.30 a week. It is not a large amount, but that is the Democrats' estimate. I have seen other estimates from the Australian Labor Party, not of $1.30 but of $1.50. To an average person that seems a significant amount, until we start to analyse where that money is spent and by whom and what could have been done with it if it had been collected.

I think that honourable members opposite now need to look at the options they could have supported. I think we need to assess the statements made by the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats at the time, Senator Colin Mason. He said:

Can we now mess around with the Budget a little and if so how much? Clearly the Senate has the right to alter the Budget a little. It has an equal right to alter it a great deal. I suggest the difference is merely quantitative. That is a dangerous path that would lead the way to the re-enactment of the events of 1975.

Today the Democrats have had a change of heart. One would expect it to be an expedient change of heart. The complete loss of credibility that I believe will as a result accrue to the Australian Democrats will be reflected in the next election. Keeping people honest is not just a matter of losing one's principles when one makes decisions. Contrary to what the Australian Labor Party has stated , the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has stated that this tax is not regressive. The Australian Labor party tonight for its authority quoted what a person from the University of New South Wales has said. The Labor Party matches that person's and its judgment, made on the run, against the whole of the expertise of the OECD, an economic group that has experience and deep understanding of the processes of indirect taxes. The amount of shortfall this financial year will be $132m and in a total year it will be $330m.

Let us look at some of the main items and see whether the tax would be regressive. Let us consider the impact of sales tax on the cost of housing and building materials. For an average house built anywhere in Australia today it would mean an additional cost of $500. That is a total of the principal and the interest charged and amounts to a total of $1.39 a week extra for the purchase of such a house. Over the past few months increases amounting to 18 per cent have been granted in wages in the building industry. That will increase the cost of an average home by $3,600. The Opposition is quibbling tonight about $1.39 and it has approved and encouraged wage claims of that type.

Let us look at the activities of local government and State government in this area. A local council in my area has put a surcharge of $2,000 on each block of land on which houses will be built. It has done that because it claims it needs that money to meet the cost of services that it will provide. Compared with sales tax revenue, that is a huge amount of money. If we are really serious about the problems of home buyers, a one per cent increase in interest rates will, on an average house, mean the payment of an additional $7.69 a week. The impact of sales tax in the housing area is insignificant. In fact, builders have said to me: 'We are pleased to have some sort of check on the cash economy in the building industry because it will force people who work on a total cash basis to contribute'. If we look at the clothing and footwear areas in exactly the same way we will find that the facts are different from the way they have been presented by both the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. For instance, for a pair of shoes which would normally be worn by school children, with an average price of $25, the additional sales tax will be 63c. If we allow a figure of 10 per cent, the total cost of living increase on that pair of shoes would be $2.50. An amount of 63c is a small amount to pay on a pair of shoes.

I am talking about people who are in need and who are buying at the lower end of the scale. I am not talking about the middle class or the pseudo- intellectuals who come into this place. I am talking about the average person with whom those on the other side of this place have not associated for years. The additional cost for an average dress for an Australian housewife, costing around $30, will be 75c. The additional cost on a pair of sneakers for a school child will be 28c. Moving to the upper and middle income brackets, a person who pays $100 for a pair of shoes will contribute in indirect tax $2.50 towards Federal revenue. We should compare that with the additional cost of 63c for a pair of children's shoes. I do not think the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats realise that the people who will pay this tax will be those with middle or substantial incomes. They are the largest consumers. Not only do they consume more but they also consume more luxury and high cost goods. On a uniform for a primary school boy the additional cost of the sales tax, spread over the whole year, would be $6.25. I can go on in regard to essential items of clothing for the family and indicate that the arguments the opposition has advanced cannot be sustained.

Many small amounts aggregated in this way can provide a number of options for assisting, once more, those people in need. I refer to the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. I have mentioned it already. An amount of $674m has been set aside to allow first home buyers to receive a grant of up to $2,000 if they have their savings in an approved account with an approved agency. In Australia last year 37,000 grants were made. An amount of $330m, which amount the Democrats have said they will not approve, would provide for 165,000 grants. To put it another way, we could supply grants to the same number of people not at the rate of $2, 000 per applicant but at a rate of $8,000 per applicant. Let us look at the amount of money required to provide an interest subsidy on an average home loan of $40,000. A 4 per cent subsidy would cost something like $100m a year. The $ 330m a year that we hope will come to revenue would give the Government the option of providing an interest subsidy for 60,000 homes to the extent of 12 per cent.

The Opposition and the Australian Democrats say that they are concerned for the underprivileged and for those who are being ripped off. They will save these individuals $1.30 a week, yet they will deny the options of worthwhile housing programs or worthwhile support for home buyers. In 1981-82, $1,040m will be provided for family allowances. The additional $330m would allow the family allowance to be increased by 33 per cent. I refer the House to Budget Paper No. 1 where the amounts are indicated clearly. Let us look at the situation of dependent spouses. It is claimed that they are in need of assistance. As members of parliament, we all understand the circumstances which make things more difficult for them. Under the Income Tax Assessment Act and the requirements of tax returns, the rebate during 1981-82 of $830 which is the current rebate for the dependent spouses, will cost the Government $615m. The amount that has so far been denied by the Senate would provide the option for a 50 per cent increase in the amounts allowable for dependent spouses-an increase from $830 to $1,200 under the Act. Compare that $8 a week for a dependent spouse and a family with the miserable $1.30 that is being saved by the glorious white knights on the other side of King's Hall. It is unbelievable that such a trumped up charge against the Government can be made for such a small amount of saving right across the board, involving all families wealthy or poor. The options which would have been available to the Government and which could have been offered to the community appear to be vanishing. It is the most poorly conceived decision I have seen for a long time in these Houses of the Parliament. The change of mind has indicated an on-the-run change of approach which will have long and lasting detrimental effects on the leaders of the parties that oppose this legislation.

If the Government does not provide benefits in this way, what options does it have in regard to cutting expenditure? Reducing the size of the Public Service is an option. That is something the Government has sought to do since coming to power. Could the Government cut the supporting mother's benefit? I do not think that is an option. The Government could also consider its building programs. The Government's record in trying to contain public expenditure has not been equalled by any other government in the history of Australia. It has had remarkable success in containing costs and reducing charges and the benefits of that are flowing through to the Australian community and being turned to the best advantage. Choosing to accept only those parts of a Budget which an Opposition party or faction group happens to like can bring great changes to the way in which the Houses of Parliament operate. The size and cost of government may be larger than is wanted but poorly conceived decisions do not allow for proper management. An instantaneous change of direction which denies capacity for management can have serious and long-lasting effects.

I turn again to the taxes proposed by the Australian Labor Party. Of course, members of the Labor Party are all for tax cuts. They have not said where they stand on indirect taxes and whether they would increase them. They like the thought of imposing resource taxes, which are indirect taxes, and they like the idea of imposing special taxes for medical costs. They like also the idea of wealth taxes but they have not said exactly where they stand on tax matters. The Government has to say where it stands and the shift from direct to indirect taxes is a most sensible and equitable approach to spreading the responsibility and forcing those who are avoiding paying tax to make a contribution to the real needs of the nation. The smart attitudes and actions may prove beneficial in the short term but may also prove to be of real regret to those parties that have adopted and instigated them.

It seems to me quite amazing that he can twist figures to support fallacious arguments. He produced figures out of the air and then quoted them as though they were factual. What is more, he talked as though he had some understanding of the situation of low income earners. It must be some time since he has had any contact with these people. To make comparisons between the amount of money that the low income earners spend on the necessities of life and the amount of money the higher income earners spend is absolutely ridiculous. Of course, the honourable member for Mitchell has now left the chamber. He is not prepared to listen to the arguments which I will now put to honourable members and which will explain the ridiculousness of his points of view.
—They don't like to hear the truth.

—As the honourable member for Hindmarsh says, they do not like to hear the truth. I find it equally amazing that Government members hypocritically charge the Australian Labor Party with acting irresponsibly over our rejection of the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on clothing, footwear, building masterials and reading materials, which are the main items affected by the Bills before us.
