Since that time we have all been overwhelmed with an avalanche of written protests from our constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of these taxes will fall most heavily on the poorer people because they are taxes on the necessities of life. By all means, let the Government tax luxury goods but clothing, building materials, books and tools are not in the luxury category. Even a pauper must wear clothes or risk imprisonment for indecency. Books and journals provide valuable information to the community and are essential in a society which believes in individual freedoms and in the ability of people to make their own meaningful decisions. If the provision of information is to be taxed it follows that the increased cost will mean that the poorer people will not be able to afford to obtain the information. Obviously, that is what this Government is aiming for-a society in which only the rich and the powerful will have access to information. Building materials are also essential. The proposed sales tax would considerably increase the price of a house even beyond the present high level which is far higher than most young people can afford.

It has been mentioned by other honourable members, but it is worth repeating because it must be hammered home to the Australian people, that the Government has no mandate to impose these taxes. They were not mentioned in the Government' s 1980 election policies and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said publicly that the Government would not consider the introduction of indirect taxation unless there was a comparable cut in personal income tax. The Treasurer has broken his word and the Government has deceived the electorate. Of course, it is clear that if these most regressive taxes had been part of the Government's election platform it would have been thrown out of office in no uncertain terms. Instead, in the last election campaign, it fraudulently fooled the electors by suggesting that the Labor Party would introduce a wealth tax-a totally untrue proposition-while all along it intended to introduce its own new sales tax.

I wonder whether it is the Government's intention to introduce some new proposals before the electors of the Federal electorate of Lowe go the the polls . Perhaps we ought to have the honourable member for Mitchell campaigning there. I think he would win quite a few votes for us in that seat. How much longer will it take the Australian people to discover that this Government has remained in office for 6 1/2 years because of a blatant fraud and a deceit of the electorate ? While the Treasurer huffs and puffs about responsibilities he permits the growth of a tax avoidance industry which is now estimated to be worth $7,000m a year. It is not the low income earners who benefit from this most immoral of industries, but the rich and the powerful ruling elements of our society. The fact is that the Treasurer knows that low income earners are no friends of his Government. He can tax them with impunity but he will not act effectively to prevent high income earners from avoiding their legitimate taxes.

Another point which has been made previously, but which it is important to emphasise, is the inflationary aspect of these new sales taxes. It has been estimated that the consumer price index will rise by 1.1 per cent as a result of these taxes. Inflation, which has already reached double figures, will climb even higher. The increasing level of inflation is another example of the complete ineptitude of the Treasurer in handling the economy of this country. Of course, he is now blaming the international economic scene and the Reagan Government for our high inflation level and our high interest rates. What hyprocrisy this is when it is quite clear that he intends to recommend the acceptance of the deregulation proposals in the report by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, which will bind us even closer to the ravenous maw of the international money market.

Whilst it is true that we cannot avoid the effects of world-wide economic trends it is not true to say that lower and moderate income earners cannot be protected from the direct effect of the harsh monetarist policies of Professor Milton Friedman.

An extension of sales taxes will only serve to increase the harshness of inflation and high interest rates. What is needed is a complete restructuring of the taxation system which will ensure that those Australians who can afford to pay both indirect and direct taxes are made liable for those taxes. These are the people the honourable member for Mitchell knows so well. They can afford to pay these taxes but not the lower income earners of our society. Low and moderate income earners must be relieved of the higher rates of personal taxes and direct taxes on the necessities of life. Honourable members on the Government side of this House keep asking: 'If those taxes are not imposed, where is the Goverment revenue coming from?' I heard the Minister who was previously sitting at the table saying just that to the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child). Surely the answer is obvious and it ought to have been obvious to him. If the Government was really prepared to crack down on tax avoiders in 1982-83 it could obtain three times as much revenue as $330m which is the full year amount of the 2 1/2 per cent sales taxes provision contained in the Bills before us. I support the rejection of these most iniquitous of bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate before the House this evening is really about changing the incidence of taxation in Australia and changing the way in which the tax burden falls upon different groups of people within our society. It is about creating circumstances in which the burden, which falls particularly on pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, can be relieved. It is a debate on giving people a choice about how they will spend their money and how they will pay for the services that they and the rest of the community demand. Despite the fact that total tax in Australia is a lower proportion of gross domestic product than taxation in all the countries that we regard as our major trading partners, except Japan, it is still true that taxation is an issue in Australia. The marginal rates of tax are obviously rising as earnings rise. As it was made clear in Question Time this morning, a significantly greater proportion of the work force, of wage and salary earners, will be paying tax at the 46 per cent rate than there was when those scales were introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously there is a cry for relief. It is true to say that there are cries for relief coming to the Government from all sides-from the media, the Opposition and different groups within the community. It is understandable that that should be so because there is no doubt that the present level of income taxation is biting harder than it has done in earlier times. However, there are no offers of expenditure cuts or of savings which come with those clamours for relief in taxation. The only option that really faces the Government is an option to change the mix of taxation. I refer to a change in the mix that would allow significant numbers of people to pay tax at a lower marginal rate and to allow all to have a greater choice in deciding whether to pay indirect taxes or direct taxes.

It has been argued by many honourable members who have spoken in this debate and on this issue that the change in the mix of taxation to increase the amount of revenue that comes from indirect taxes as opposed to direct taxes is regressive. But it has been argued quite competently by my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) earlier this evening, as well as by my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) on earlier occasions , that it is not necessarily regressive, that people obviously consume and, therefore, pay indirect tax, according to their means-that not everyone buys the cheapest or the most expensive pair of shoes; that not everyone buys the cheapest or the most expensive suit.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously do.
—If I could afford to shop at the honourable member's store, I would obviously have to make a submission to the Remuneration Tribunal for far greater pay.
—We are a gentleman's store. You would never get in the door.
—Order! The honourable member for Hume will address himself to the question.

—The point that people plan their expenditure according to their income has to be valid, and if indirect taxes accrue, obviously richer or relatively better off people will pay a higher level of indirect taxation than will people who are spending less money.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Australian Democrats, and the Opposition in this place, are seeking to do is to stop this reform. What they are really about is to take away the choice that people are being offered under this legislation as to how they will pay their taxation. This reform, this chance which is being offered to the Australian people to have a better mix of taxation, to take pressure off the amount of money which must be collected at present by way of direct taxation and to increase the amount being collected by way of indirect taxation is being frustrated by the action of the Australian Democrats and the Labor Opposition in this Parliament.

It is interesting to look at what those parties are really about and who they think they are protecting. They are not really protecting the people that they say they are protecting, because those people will pay income tax at continually higher rates. That will be so because the opportunity for reform of the income taxation system is being frustrated by the actions of the Opposition. The continuation of taxation at unnecessarily high levels is obviously the result of such action.

The Treasurer has made it clear that, in a full year, about $330m will be denied the Government as a result of these Bills not being passed by the Parliament. That is a significant amount, the extent of which makes it more difficult for the Government to take the sort of steps that it would want to take in regard to taxation policy and to achieve the sort of reforms that everyone wants achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about tax avoidance?

—The honourable member refers piously to tax avoidance. It has been said on so many occasions that it is almost trite; this Government has moved more in the area of tax avoidance than has any other government since Federation . Certainly, the Labor Government of 1973-75 was notorious for its ignorance of tax avoidance and its lack of action in that area. It took absolutely no action at all. The present Government has proceeded to pursue tax avoiders with great vigour-something for which I think the Treasurer must take great credit.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the overall question of taxation and the change in the mix, we find ourselves inevitably in a debate about the management of the economy, the options that we, as a Government, are pursuing and the choices that an alternative government might make. We are putting firm alternatives to the people. We are saying that we would like to change the mix in taxation, would like to provide alternatives in the whole way in which people provide the funds that the economy needs to provide the sorts of services that they as taxpayers demand and for which they have to pay taxes if they are to receive them.

However, despite the fact that newspapers and the Opposition on opening days of Parliament grasp at all the bad news and seek to make enormous capital out of some of its elements-I do not deny that the news is less good than one would like it to be-the question of economic management and performance in Australia must be kept in perspective. The fact that in the last couple of weeks there have been some areas in which the figures have been soft does not mean that the deluge is upon us, that we are faced with economic ruin, or that the policies of the Fraser-Anthony Government have failed. It is a hiccup, perhaps, in a long, strong and steady economic performance which has brought this economy to a stage at which those sorts of things can be handled as we progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still the best in the world.

—I take that point: It is still the best economy in the world. Those members of the Labor Party who have been tripping around the world over the Christmas recess have all returned and said: 'Thank God we live in Australia and have the sort of economic management that we have'.
—God's own nation.

—I thank the honourable member for that comment. In this country we are experiencing growth. That is something that is not being experienced in other economies around the world. In the six months to September, the growth in gross domestic product in Australia was 3.6 per cent. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is predicting a growth of 3 per cent for the current year, as against the OECD average of slightly above one per cent; so in growth terms Australia is performing three times better than the OECD average .

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia investment is strong. People are confident. That does not indicate that the people who are making investment decisions are frightened off by the sort of horrible predictions coming from the Labor Party and from some media commentators. New fixed capital expenditure is expected to be up by 25 per cent- a quarter-on the figure for the last financial year. That is on top of what everyone realises was an incredibly high new capital expenditure figure for last year. At 11.3 per cent for the calendar year just ended inflation, although high , is still very favourable compared with the OECD average figures.

Consumption in Australia is still extraordinarily strong. Real household disposable income after tax rose by nearly $3 billion in 1980-81. Motor vehicle sales were 6 per cent higher in December than they were in that month in the previous year. In the quarter to Christmas, retail sales were 13 per cent higher than they were in the previous year. In comparison, in the United States average spending power was 3.6 per cent lower in 1981 than it was in 1980. It is unarguable that Australia is going from strength to strength. Unemployment of 6. 4 per cent in January 1982 is still slightly lower than it was last January. The average unemployment figure for 1981 was 5.7 per cent, whereas in 1978, 1979 and 1980 the average for each year was comfortably over 6 per cent. Again, on international comparisons, Australia is still performing relatively well. At the moment the United States unemployment level is around 8 1/2 per cent. Great Britain, as everybody knows, has tragic unemployment levels of over 3 million people or around 10 per cent of the work force.

Australia is performing well. What people need to understand is that if we want to make comparisons with the previous year or with three years ago things may not be as good as we would like them to be, but if we make comparisons with the rest of the world, with countries with which we trade and with which we compare ourselves, we are performing extraordinarily well. The money supply announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the Budget is still broadly on target. What we must also take into consideration when we discuss the sorts of policies that the Government is putting before the Parliament is that there are significant external factors. The Treasurer said yesterday that if the United States continues to run deficits of the order of $100 billion, obviously there must be impacts on other economies and related economies. There is undeniable stagnation in the world economy. That has an effect on trade. In Australia the effect on trade has been dramatic but I venture to suggest that even if the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) were Prime Minister or Minister for Trade and Resources he could not have improved upon the performance that we have experienced.

In the seven months to January, imports in Australia were up by 16 per cent whereas exports were down by 3 per cent. That is not as a result of policies of the Australian Government. It is as a result of stagnation in the world economy. The mining companies which are selling their products on world markets have all experienced disastrous periods. I will cite some of the figures that have been released in recent times. The profit of Mount Isa Mines Ltd went from $76m to a loss of $4m, the profit of Alcan Australia Ltd went from $19m down to $7, the profit of Comalco Ltd from $75m down to $28m, the profit of Western Mining Corporation Ltd from $33m down to $7m, the profit of Bougainville Copper Ltd from $92m to $29m and the profit of North Broken Hill Ltd from $19m to $9m. These are all companies which depend extraordinarily heavily on export markets and on world commodity prices for their revenues. With the fact that their revenues are being so adversely affected by the sort of world economy that is being experienced at the moment, it is no surprise that Australia's trade figures are down as they are, taken with the relatively flat performance in agricultural prices on export markets. The Australian farming community has to accept lower prices than might normally be accepted if the international economy were buoyant. Obviously, the management of the United States economy has a significant effect on that. It is a matter which is beyond the control of governments in countries of the size of Australia.

Similarly, the effect on interest rates is as a result of overseas pressures. It is inevitable that Australia will be affected by consistent and high interest rates overseas. Again, Australia has performed relatively well. We must acknowledge that we are not an economic island. That is a fact. Interest rates have their effects in other areas and I acknowledge that in Australia at the moment housing is an area in which the performance is less than satisfactory. If the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) was not the Minister for Housing, I hate to think of the mess that things would be in. But it is obvious that a price has to be paid for excessive demands elsewhere in the economy, especially from the wages sector. If people make those sorts of demands, and if governments are to control money supplies in the way in which they do and which I acknowledge they must, it is obvious that there must be effects in other areas . Housing is one such area which is certainly feeling the effects.

The thesis which I put to the House tonight is that Australia is controlling well those areas which it can control. In those areas where international pressures bring forces into the Australian economy which are totally beyond our control, this economy has been strong enough to be able to resist the excesses that arise from those international pressures. There is still no question as to who will provide the best economic management of the Australian economy. It is the Liberal- National Country Party coalition. It is beyond dispute that this Government is providing the best economic management of the Australian economy.

The wheel comes full circle back to the subject of taxation. I support strongly the sales tax measures before the House because they provide for a broadening of the income tax base. They provide the Government with the opportunity to be able to alter the mix that presently exists and which we all acknowledge falls too heavily on the burden of wage and salary earners. By denying the Government this legislation, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are frustrating the cause of taxation reform in Australia.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Some people just cannot cop it. The Australian Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research has conducted post Budget analyses of the Government's tax changes every year since 1975 and has found that the combined effects of the tax changes have consistently been to the advantage of the rich over the poor. This is so despite the protestations of the Government. What reason have we to feel there will be any change in the future? There is no reason at all particularly when we look at the specific effects of the sales tax increases and the fact that Government members resort to political jargon to cover up the fact that these are Bills dealing specifically with additional sales tax. They deal specifically with making people pay more money for wanting to educate their children by buying books. They will pay more money if they want to build or furnish a house. They will pay more money if they want to buy food because of packaging cost increases. This is legislation which stinks. There is no way around that.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of ordinary and lower income earners with whom I still have close contact I am only thankful that at last the Australian Democrats are showing a little conscience and thinking of joining with us in the Senate to put a stop to what this morally deficient Government has been doing in trying to pass this legislation. The Government does not know what it is talking about when someone like the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) suggests that maybe we could give housing grants in place of food or clothing. Lower income people have not a hope in the world of getting a house. They have a very limited amount of money to spend every week. If the sales tax legislation is passed they just will not be able to manage that extra weekly amount to be able to live decently. The sort of attitude coming from the Government today is reflected in the Consumer Casebook newspaper report which is backed and put forward by Sir William Knox, Queensland Minister for Employment and Labour Relations and who is responsible for consumer affairs. This is a typical Liberal viewpoint. The article is headed 'A dozen ways to eat well for less money'. The Minister suggests that people who are on lower incomes should, for instance, befriend a farmer. The article reports:

A farmer can sell you over-ripe produce. A bargain basket of aging mushrooms can be sliced, sauteed in butter, frozen in ice-cube trays and stored for when needed. Too soft tomatoes are great for sauces.
It also suggests:
Plan one meatless day a week.
And
Cheaper bread: One or two day old bread can be bought from some hot bread kitchens for about half the price.
Ah, it is very funny if one is not on a lower income and having to cop that sort of advice from Government Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't know what it is like to be poor.

—The honourable member does not know what he is talking about. Leon Pearce of the Courier-Mail has also investigated the situation of many people in our society. In the 16 February edition of the paper, he asked: 'Is this what our old people really deserve?'. He then put an objective report of what is happening in our society today. He mentioned that only 42.8 per cent of widows own their own homes and more than 89 per cent of supporting parents do not own their own homes. The people who do not own their homes are on the sharpest edge of poverty. The Government offers them $8 a week rent allowance. Honourable members would be aware that $40 a week is the minimum for the most meagre accommodation. What concerns me is that these are people, not statistics; they are people living in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Frank Cooke of the Pensioners League in Queensland stated:
The first thing you have to do when you go on the pension is to go on short rations.
It's easy, after a few days. You put off having lunch, you look for things to do. Late in the afternoon, you wait for tea.
By doing that, a pensioner can save up for something he really fancies, like a tin of salmon.

Mr Cooke said he had heard stories about little old ladies eking out their pensions with tinned dog or cat food but that he could not believe this. He is on the level in describing the way he lives. He cannot believe that this would happen. He said:
Have you ever smelled that stuff? I can't stay in the room when someone opens a can.

It became a joke when extra sales tax on dog food was vaunted. People were writing in to ask: 'What right have pensioners and lower income people to have pets anyway?' The truth came out. I know it is fact that these pensioners are eating dog food to get their weekly meat supplement. These are the people who will be affected by the introduction of this infamous sales tax legislation.

The question is not entirely whether a shift to indirect taxation is advisable. Is it advisable today? Is it advisable in 1982? Can any honourable member opposite honestly say that additional sales tax and additional financial burdens should be put on the shoulders of the people already bowed down trying to decide between expensive health insurance and expensive doctors fees, who are meeting the extra mortgage payments each week, trying to keep up with the 11 per cent inflation rate and looking at 20 per cent interest rates? I ask honourable members to be realistic. When honourable members consider average weekly earnings they must see that this tax is a burden for ordinary people. The Government should not be playing around with political jargon and Government members should not vote for regressive legislation to bring in such sales tax.

As I said before, this legislation is not only incompassionate but also reflects gross mismanagement. I believe that there are Government members and Government back benchers who would agree with that statement. They would agree with the terms of the Asprey report which suggested that sales tax increases should be brought in, as I said, only in conjunction with income tax reductions. There is no suggestion that there will be reductions or that there will be any growth under this Government in welfare payments. In these circumstances, I believe that we should not allow such legislation to pass through this chamber. I am aware how honourable members will be voting but I certainly am putting my faith and hope in the fact that in the Senate, the Democrats will join forces with the Labor Party and will reject legislation, the enactment of which would be bad for all of Australia. What is proposed in this legislation reflects on our privileged position in this chamber and our higher weekly incomes when compared with those people who have been given very raw deals by their elected government.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October 1981, on motion by Mr Street:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill, which was the subject of a Government statement on 20 August 1981, was introduced on 22 October 1981. At the time the statement was issued we of the Opposition indicated that we favoured the sort of centre that was proposed to be established and we were anxious to talk about matters such as land reform, energy resources for developing countries and certainly assistance for student training in those countries. The Bill gives effect to the Government 's decision as announced on 20 August 1981. The function of the Centre is to mobilise and expand Australia's research capacity so as to assist developing countries in agricultural and related areas and to develop an expanded, better co-ordinated and more identifiable Australian effort aimed at achieving multinational self-sufficiency in developing countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The significant thing is that the Centre will not engage in any research activity. Basically it will contract out research work to bodies such as universities, State departments, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and private individuals and organisations. There will be a heavy accent, according to the Government, in involving scientists and institutions from developing countries. The support services for the Centre will be provided by the Australian Development Assistance Board. The Policy Advisory Council of the Centre will consist of 17 ministerially appointed members from universities, the CSIRO, State agricultural departments and the like. Pending the establishment of that Council, Sir John Crawford has agreed to act as chairman of an interim council. There will be a board of management of six members to conduct and control the affairs of the Centre. The Centre will have a director and about 10 professional staff and support services will be provided, as I said, by ADAB and also by the Department of Foreign Affairs.

We of the Opposition support this Bill but we have some reservations. We might note them in this fashion. We say the Bill will not do much, if anything, in key development areas such as the need for land reform. That was the subject of our comment at the time the statement was made on 20 August 1981. We want to make the point that Australia should be far more active in this area of land reform and we should perhaps make it a condition of receiving aid. These criticisms are relevant because in the statement the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) talked about the need for more efficient use of available land resources. The Bill contains provisions for a review of the Centre's operations after 10 years. We think that is too long a period, so we propose to move some amendments in the Committee stage. We think there should be a review at an earlier time. I think those amendments have already been circulated to honourable members.

But we must mention some things which are pretty obvious to us when we look at the resources, for example, of ADAB. Those resources, as we are aware, are already very much strained because of the razor gang's deliberations. The resources of the Department of Foreign Affairs equally are strained and in fact the Department is now providing some administrative support for ADAB. Whilst institutional and organisational arrangements exist in theory, it appears very clear that in practice we would not have the capacity to do the work. The Minister has said that all research work will be contracted out. Given the facilities that we know exist at CSIRO and in other places this is a bit short sighted. Australia possibly could not undertake the research. The CSIRO and other Government instrumentalities have certainly built up their operations over a period and in the view of all Australians they employ some of the best brains in the country. It is important to give research work to them rather than contracting it out. It would build up their image, ability and incentive and the hope that they have a future and an expanding role, not a limited life or a contracting role. We find that the Government is anxious to cut scientific research programs and then introduces this counterbalance, which is quite extraordinary, of contracting work out to private enterprise the cost of which we submit will be significantly greater and I do not think the result will be as good. Certainly it will not be any better. We think they are worthwhile matters to mention at this time.

One matter that we need to talk about generally is how we can go about aid from an Australian point of view. We of the Opposition have expressed our views on aid for developing countries. We support many of the concepts of the Brandt report. But we really should be taking some initiative. In Australia we have the opportunity to do that. We ought to be working towards what we in the Opposition call the reality. For example, the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting last year dealt with the major issues of the so-called North-South Dialogue. Those issues involved matters which are pretty basic, that is, food, energy, trade and financial systems. One could say that some modest contribution was made at that conference. Also in October the Cancun Conference was held in Mexico. If one leaves out all the rhetoric, all the padding, all the publicity, all the bombast , it was a flop. It was a flop because President Reagan decided even before he went there that the United States would be unable to do anything in the four major areas where effort was needed. Just to give the balance again in the super -power situation, the Soviet Union did not even bother to answer an invitation to attend the Cancun Conference. So the United States went to the conference with a very closed mind and an equally tightly closed fist. We have the result that it does not share the Minister's perceptions of the need to help the poorer countries other than, of course, by selling them weapons which is the greatest business in the world today. While the United States has the doubtful distinction of selling the most, it is closely pursued by the Soviet Union as second in that field.

I believe efforts by countries such as ours are essential if we are to contribute to a more equit- able economic order. It is essential also because we have to look after the hungry in their millions. There is a need for land reform . The Minister makes the point that the world capita food production declined in 1980 for the second year running and that cereal stocks are at their lowest level for some years. We ought to have a look at some of the reasons. The Minister mentioned Australia's support for the world food program and for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation. Unfortunately, the opportunity to make a contribution to assist developing countries was not taken up by the Government. I suggest it was because Treasury advised that it should not do it. It was very shortsighted advice because the Government refused to back moves for an international food finance facility. That was a very serious mistake.

There is a more current and perhaps urgent omission in the Minister's statement . He referred to the urgent need for 'nutritionally adequate food supplies and effective food storage and distribution'. We should be very active in encouraging land reform in general and especially in the countries and the areas which will benefit from the research. Would it not be better, for example, if the United States could be persuaded to help El Salvador implement some reforms in the land holding system instead of sending in more arms which create more deaths? My experience in visiting a number of developing countries in which we have had aid projects is that whilst our research is helping them there is virtually no land reform. So all that is achieved perhaps, at the expense of improving the yield, is to give more wealth to the group that holds the land or controls the land. The poor who hold small tracts of land are gradually persuaded to leave and the big land owners then expand and buy more land. The peasant can stay on the land as a labourer. More often than not, he drifts to the city to live in slums and is exploited by those who own factories, the suggestion being that it is economic development to work in a factory for as little as $1 a day. In my view it would be far more effective to be on one's own land producing food, not only for oneself and the family but also for the neighbourhood. I think that ought to be the position.

The Minister spoke about 'more efficient use of available land resources'. I could not agree more, but what I am saying is that we must insist on this question of aid and that recipient governments make some effort at land reform. We should be looking at our research assistance to projects which make more equitable use of available land resources. Again, there is the question of co- ordination and regular review. The Minister identified a lack of co-ordination in our past programs. In addition to co-ordination, our aid program in general- this is relevant to this Centre-needs rigorous assessment. Some of our field and research programs need to be examined to see whether they are good or need to be modified.

I have expressed in the past reservations about our Program of Aid for Disabled People, in the southern Philippines. In the case of this Bill I note that both the need for the Centre itself, as well as its operations will be reviewed after 10 years. I think that is too long, particularly since it will be an independent statutory body. In our view there ought to be a review after six years in order to establish the effectiveness and efficiency of the Centre and in order to re- assess the basic priorities. Six years would enable Council members to have served two terms in office and thus be in a good position to review the work of the Centre and to decide whether its activities provided good value for the money that has been spent.

We propose to move in Committee the appropriate amendments to what is called the sunset clause, clause 43 of the Bill. We are going to suggest a term of eight years. In the supplementary clause we will be talking about the expiration of the six years. The Minister placed great emphasis on the role that the Australian Development Assistance Bureau will need to play. We note that this Centre will rely completely on ADAB for arrangements for academic training for scientists from developing countries. This is also to be the case with the extension programs and field programs to be conducted by the Centre. Again, I make the point that the razor gang cuts have slashed ADAB even further so as to hinder its ability to staff its headquarters and posts and to supervise the functions with which it is already charged. Furthermore, the Centre is to be located close to the Bureau. We would like to know where this would be because at present the Bureau is located in five separate locations throughout Canberra. We also note that the support services for the Centre will be provided by the appropriate sections within the Department of Foreign Affairs.

Once again, as a result of the razor gang cuts that Department is at a point where it is struggling to perform some of the tasks expected of it, including the provision of administrative support for ADAB. The Department of Foreign Affairs will also have to look after the travel arrangements for the Centre as, no doubt, many trips will have to be made abroad by the Centre's staff and to Australia by scientists from the developing countries who will sit on the Council. In our view, Foreign Affairs staff will not be able to cope with this additional work load.

I have visited a number of overseas posts. Some of them are in the poorer countries where services are limited. All such posts were struggling to cope with less than adequate support services from the overburdened home department in Canberra. There will be a good deal of high level management for the Centre, having both a policy advisory board and a board of management. The Centre itself will have some high-priced help. The Director will be a person of 'outstanding ability'. His professional staff will be 'of such stature as to command respect among scientists in Australia and in developing countries'. How the Minister proposes to recruit and to train staff of such calibre with the current level of Public Service conditions of service is something that we cannot really understand. It appears that the Centre will be very top heavy as the administrative support to be provided by ADAB and Foreign Affairs is likely to be just a pack of cards. When we talk about the Policy Advisory Council I hope that there will be an opportunity for non-governmental organisations to have some representation on that Council, certainly an input to the Council to be able to reflect the valuable contribution which it already makes to our programs in developing countries.

In summary, while the concept of creating the Centre as a clearing house for requests for assistance from developing countries in agricultural development is an excellent one, the administrative arrangements seem to be very inadequate. I think that the Government's own misguided policies of practising false economies in important areas will undermine this project. I hope that this does not happen . I believe that aid management in Australia needs to be improved and streamlined but perhaps all that might happen with the creation of this Centre is another stillborn statutory body. It should not happen because we are in an area where we can have a very significant influence, which we already have; that is, the Pacific and the developing countries in the Pacific and also in the areas immediately to our north. I emphasise the need to get the best results from Australia's aid. I feel land reform will be the key in what I have said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's initiative to establish the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research is one which I have great pleasure in supporting. For many years Australia, under various governments, has played a relatively leading role in the whole concept of international relief and assistance to developing countries.

SPEECH.PARA: As a rich and, certainly agriculturally, a leading nation in the world, it is not unreasonable that we should in fact be trying to associate our aid programs wherever possible with those areas in which we are most technologically capable of assisting. In a sense this new proposal for the establishment of an Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research has some resemblance to an organisation in Canada known as the International Development Resources Centre. Perhaps the biggest difference between the two is that the Australian derivative is much more limited in its scope. For example clause 5 of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill provides that the functions of the Centre are to be:
(a) to formulate the programs and policies with respect to agricultural research for either or both of the following purposes:
(i) identifying agricultural problems of developing countries;
(ii) finding solutions to agricultural problems of developing countries;
(b) to commission agricultural research by persons or institutions in Australia -
Meaning persons or institutions which will be able to make a contribution in that area-
(c) to communicate to persons and institutions the results of such agricultural research.

In my opinion the last requirement-namely, that to communicate with persons and institutions in those areas-will be one of the major areas in which this proposed new institution will be able to make a very significant contribution.

One of the major problems which have been emphasised in the United Nations for many years is the problem of technological transfer between the developed world and the underdeveloped world. Whilst this institution will have as its fundamental definition a rather restricted interpretation of 'agriculture'-I refer specifically to the definition in the Bill of 'agriculture', namely, 'such uses of land as are prescribed for the purposes of this definition'-I think a tremendous amount can be fitted within that context. However, on the first reading I am a little concerned that technology relevant to agriculture should also be something which is included within the terms of reference of the proposed Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.

My observations in West Africa last July and my experience as Australian representative on the Colombo Plan Council have led me to believe that one of the fundamental problems the developed world, especially the Commonwealth, may be facing is that whilst we are training as many people as we possibly can, often in fairly esoteric fields ostensibly so that they can return to their countries and make a contribution, often the reality is that there is not the infrastructure in those developing countries to enable those people usefully to employ the skills they have learned at not inconsiderable cost overseas.

That leads me to suggest, therefore, that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) and the Government may be prepared to give consideration to another concept which I have developed as a result of my visit to Africa, namely, the establishment of an international Commonwealth university. The essence of that is that we want to get an arrangement by which there is maximum technological transfer at the minimum possible cost. One of the arguments people have often raised in the past when one has suggested the establishment of new organisations is that capital costs will be involved before such organisations will become functional. However, the establishment of a Commonwealth university should involve minimum capital costs because all the existing facilities in universities and centres of expertise already in various developed and developing Commonwealth countries would be utilised. The basic premise we would work on would be this: Let us use Africa as a example. In Commonwealth countries in Africa there are at least five major universities. Some or all of the faculties in those various universities, in terms of the region at least, already have reached a stage of international acceptability. However, for various reasons-usually financial and the availability of technological research and, of course, personnel-they have not yet reached the stage at which they are able to transfer foreign knowledge and technological capacity into effective operational techniques which can be employed in their own countries.

I give one clear example of that: At one university I visited in West Africa they were trying to develop a solar oven. The reason they wanted one was quite clear: For many generations the villagers had been systematically denuding the land of forests. The only power those people had was derived from either wood or charcoal. Therefore, the only way in which they could save what was left of the forest land was to introduce a new sort of technology. They had only two alternatives: Either they imported liquefied petroleum gas-type ovens, which would involve a foreign exchange problem, in addition to diesel, distillate and so forth, or alternatively they employed the cheapest source of power, namely, the sun. Their logical interpretation of the situation was absolutely impeccable . They decided that they must invent a cheap form of solar oven which could be utilised locally. The fact is that solar ovens have been known in many Western countries for at least the past 40 years. I found it depressing to see young students, in a sense, trying to re-invent the wheel. When I saw their library I realised that technological research material from other countries was to a large degree forbidden to those people. Their libraries either did not have the capacity to accept that material or had not linked up with other institutions of learning, universities and so forth in countries throughout the Commonwealth and elsewhere. That is just one simple, isolated example.

In another country I visited, I found that 50 per cent of the children died before reaching the age of five years. The reason is clear: The level of hygiene there is extremely poor; by our standards, medical attention is almost non- existent; and, of course, their dietary habits leave much to be desired. Therefore, the whole area of community medicine is one in which many countries in Africa desperately need assistance. The traditional way in which we have handled those sorts of problems is, firstly, to hope that the missions will solve the problems for us-frankly, they like everybody else have very limited resources-and, secondly, it seems, to take people out of their environment for training, presuming that they will all go back to their original environment and do a great job there.

The simple and sad reality is that much of the training which has been given in other countries is not necessarily relevant to the environment in which those people are expected to work. Also, often those people, having gained what they regard as very acceptable international qualifications, have a very deep-seated reluctance to go back home. Time after time those who have gone home have been put behind desks and have not been given an opportunity to utilise the skills they have gained at considerable inconvenience and cost to both the home government and the host government. Therefore, the concept of a Commonwealth university is based simply on the belief that if we can bring together the most capable people in the developing countries and inject a high level of skill and information and a capacity to train in that environment-a wide range of students , both undergraduates and more specifically graduates-with a specific intention to encourage them to take foreign technology and foreign ideas and apply them to the environment to which those people will return we will be making a massive step forward.

I must emphasise that the whole concept is based on using existing facilities, existing university buildings and existing university faculties. The other point which must be emphasised is that this is not a concept directed at theoreticians . It is not a concept directed at developing more graduates in the arts, the pure sciences and so forth. It is directed specifically at encouraging development in technological research and the application of technology. As I said earlier, at the United Nations for many years resolution after resolution has been passed urging the developed world to assist the developing countries by the transfer of technology. From my observations that simply is not taking place . Certainly it is not taking place in a manner which enables effective application by those countries. We cannot go on indefinitely with a situation in which the developed world is drawing further and further ahead of the developing world. Especially since the late 1970s, with the explosion in oil prices, we have seen in every one of those countries a chronic shortage of foreign exchange and a fundamental inability to import, at their cost, technology. It is in this sort of area that there is a crying need for us to adopt a new approach and to see what we can do to solve the problem.

The Minister in his first reading speech on this Bill made the observation that , as Australia is in the forefront of agricultural research, we have a binding obligation to make our knowledge available to less fortunate countries. He made the observation also that food security remains one of the most fundamental deficiencies of mankind. Whilst some people might argue, as Adam Smith undoubtedly would, that it is more appropriate that countries with certain physical, environmental and scientific advantages should be encouraged to develop food resources for the rest of the world, as I mentioned earlier the reality is that it is now too expensive for such countries to use scarce foreign exchange in buying food from other countries, no matter how cheap it is and irrespective of the terms under which that food is supplied. That is because in most cases those countries are running massive deficits. In terms of World Bank requirements, most of them are in considerable debt. This is because they need energy to keep the basic level of their economies moving. Unfortunately, those economies are steadily falling further and further behind.

While one can say that this is a situation in which we in the rich countries can simply sit by, shrug our shoulders and say that it is good luck for us that we live where we do, one Foreign Minister in West Africa made the observation to me that they were no longer in a situation where they were simply able to negotiate what the rich world was prepared to give them but were now in a situation where they were fighting for their very survival. As I said, when we have situations in some of those countries where 50 per cent of children below the age of five years die because they do not have the very basic requirements for life, much less for civilised life, it is quite obvious that a rich country, such as Australia, has a very pronounced role to play. Therefore I have great pleasure in supporting the Government's initiative because I am sure that the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research will be but one of the mechanisms by which it will be possible to bring together the level of technological knowledge we have in Australia, specifically relevant to agriculture, and ensure that the knowledge, expertise and experience of the specialists and the scientists in this country are able to be utilised to help these other societies.

I hope also that the private sector will be given the opportunity equally to make a contribution. Two years ago I visited the Jordanian side of the Jordan Valley and saw an Australian company which had done extremely well in the introduction of modern Australian-made technology in irrigation. I recall that in Libya a similar operation is in place-I understand it is funded by the South Australian Government-to encourage the growing of cereal crops in the desert, again using sophisticated means of irrigation. This capacity which Australia has in dry land farming is in a sense unique; possibly the only other country comparable with us is Israel. Because of these advantages, which have been developed essentially by the private sector with the co-operation of universities and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, I would hope that Australian companies which win contracts overseas, such as the ones in Jordan and Libya, will be encouraged to develop in those societies techniques which can be applied elsewhere.

Australian private sector organisations are also involved in animal breeding and development on the African continent. In both Ghana and Nigeria large tracts of land have been opened up in recent years, have been fenced, often using Austrlian fencing equipment, which is excellent, and have been stocked with cattle and provided with personnel, again from Australia. The techniques they are applying in those countries are ones developed in Australia to suit the requirements of the environment. However, the trouble is that there is no direct linkage between the enormous bank of expertise which has been built up by those people and the continuation of that expertise in the event of their ultimate departure.

As I said earlier, the Commonwealth should get a university type of structure going whereby Australian personnel working in those countries will be able to funnel their expertise back into the ACIAR and also will have the opportunity in the countries where the problem actually occurs, to link it in directly with research centres and provide training opportunities for local inhabitants. The biggest problem we have had in all of these countries is that the expert we send in, who does a good job, is ultimately replaced by an indigenous person and the standard falls. There are many reasons for this and I do not wish to go into them on this occasion. That demonstrates the fundamental problem that the information one obtains in a particular social system in a particular society is not necessarily transmitted in a short time to other societies.

We need a middle road, where that information can be brought together and utilised, where it can be applied on the ground. Perhaps over a period of years it might be possible to build up steadily a much larger cadre of people who are trained and motivated to get on and perform a standard of operation at least comparable to what was done by the foreign experts when they were there. Ultimately these countries must be managed by their own citizens. That is the goal to which we must adhere in all our foreign aid policies. It is important to find the right people to do the work and also to ensure ourselves that we have a free flow of information at the technological level which will be to the best advantage of all concerned.

I am sure that the Centre for International Agricultural Research will have a very real role to play in the communication to people and to countries' institutions the results of such agricultural research. In addition to that, as I said, it will be commissioning research in Australia and overseas directed at institutions which need to have specific things done. One of the problems we have had in the area of foreign aid is that we have always dealt on a government to government basis and regrettably, as we all know, decisions are often made for political reasons which are not necessarily economically or socially justified by the requirements of the region. By working through this organisation on a bilateral basis it will be possible to deal with individuals and institutions outside the framework of government and therefore we will be able to make a much deeper penetration and have much more influence in the societies that surround us-in Africa, the Pacific, South East Asia and ultimately, one hopes, Latin America-where there is so much more to be done if we are to build a world in which it can truly be said that all men were born equal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all members of this House realise, the Australian aid effort under the Fraser Government has remarkably little to commend it. Indeed, the record on aid has been appalling, even on the Government 's own statistics. Budget Paper No. 8 indicates that in the period since 1975 there has been a very drastic rundown in the official development assistance to the less developed countries-from 0.65 per cent of the gross national product in 1975 to 0.48 per cent in 1980. In those circumstances this legislation is unusual, but the Opposition is delighted to commend the Government on its initiative, for two reasons. First of all, the idea is commendable but, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) has pointed out, we have some grave reservations about the adminsitrative arrangements. Secondly, the Government at long last is carrying out one of the recommendations on the Committee on Australia's Relations with the Third World. It is a great pity that the Government has not seen fit to implement other recommendations of this Committee's report. I will return to some of those a little later. On page 190 of the report, the Harries Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration should be given to making greater use of Australia's agricultural expertise to help Third World countries increase food production. In particular, additional agricultural research could be conducted in Australia specifically directed at overcoming agricultural problems in developing countries. This might be funded by a separate appropriation in the aid budget.

The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Bill implements that recommendation. It concerns the whole of the very complex concept of food aid. One could be forgiven for expressing some scepticism about the provision of food aid. It is certainly a very useful way of disposing of the very large surpluses often created as a result of government subsidies and programs at the expense of the taxpayer, and also administratively it is an easy form of aid giving. However, we should realise that the impact on both the donor and the recipient can be very complex. A very sensible discussion of the issues of food aid is contained in a report, regrettably neglected, of the Australian Auditor- General's Office, which carried out an efficiency audit of the administration of the bilateral overseas aid program of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. That report points out some of the very complex considerations that should be taken into account in the administration of any food aid program.
