DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRE FOR INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH BILL 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even with the reservations about the nature of food programs it is quite clear that food aid is certainly vital to stave off famine. It is also necessary to understand that a continuing dependence on food aid by any of the recipient countries can completely distort local production and disadvantage local producers leading to a chronic inability to meet national requirements. We therefore have to strike a balance between short-term relief of hunger and the longer term aim of helping to increase the amount of agricultural products and production in developing countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in his second reading speech acknowledged that Australia, in its past performance, had acted on ad hoc requests and lacked a systematic approach to the question of food aid. This is rather remarkable when one considers that in this financial year a very significant amount of money has been placed against the food aid budget. In fact , the amount allocated for that item is of the order of $78m. So it is quite obvious that there is a need for a more systematic approach. There certainly is a need that the requests not be handled on the ad hoc basis which has been the practice hitherto. We in the Opposition trust that the new Agricultural Research Centre will provide the basis for developing a more thoughtful and useful project in our aid program in the field of food and nutrition.

The second reading speech and the Bill before us have an interesting feature. In clauses 43 and 44 of the Bill we have one of the early introductions into Australian legislation of sunset provisions, that is, that unless legislative action is taken after a certain time the Act will expire. It is indicated in clause 44 that there will be a review after the tenth year of operation and that unless legislative action is taken the Act will expire in 12 year's time. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has already indicated our concern that this period appears to be too long. We will be moving an amendment to the Bill in the Committee stage. I think 12 years is excessive but we will go into those arguments in the Committee stage.

I believe the Minister may have read of some of the experiences in the United States of America. I suppose one of the curious anomalies is that when the sunset provisions are waning in their popularity in the United States-they started in 1975 in the State of Colarado-the Australian Government is just beginning to learn about them and applying them. In the United States there has been a movement away from the sunset provisions because it was found that the administrative arrangements were such that the provisions became only a bureaucratic answer to a bureaucratic problem. I think there are particular advantages if this legislature is given a role of play in the reveiw. As I understand the arrangement so far the review would be carried out within the bureaucracy and this Parliament would not have an opportunity to make its input into the review of an organisation of a centre that the legislation of this Parliament would create. I believe that a number of very appropriate committees of this Parliament could carry out such a review. There is the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and, of course, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I hope the sunset provisions that have been incorporated in this legislation will find a place and that this Parliament will play a role-I believe a rightful role-in the review.

I mentioned earlier that the Government in introducing this legislation had acted on a recommendation of the report of the Committee on Australia's Relations with the Third World which was issued in 1979. This legislation, with its significance for bilateral relations, particularly in the form of project aid, brings to mind a continuing concern of mine about the form of aid that we apply to Papua New Guinea. I want to point out that the aid to Papua New Guinea is provided not on a basis of project assistance but on budgetary support. This budgetary support is providing funds directly into the recurrent expenditure of Papua New Guinea where the Australian side of the aid program has no opportunity for evaluation and no opportunity to see how effectively that aid is being spent . In fact, I think the whole notion of a budgetary support program as distinct from what is implicit in this Bill is counter-productive. The report of the World Bank on Papua New Guinea in 1977 issued a warning. In that warning it stated:

Rather than continuing to base them on Australian standards, Papua New Guinea needs to bring its expectations, living standards, and levels of public and private costs into a better relation to what it will be able to sustain from its own resources. Nowhere does this need show up more than in the public sector; nearly half of Papua New Guinea's present government costs are supportable only because Australia is willing to pay for them.

That warning has not been heeded. I suppose that one of the reasons it has not been heeded is this notion of providing budget support programs as distinct from the type of informed bilateral projects that would be incorporated under the terms of this Bill. We have only to look at some of the criticisms of the Bank of Papua New Guinea. This is not Australians criticising the performances of the Papua New Guinean Government but the Bank of Papua New Guinea which strongly criticised what it described as the questionable level of spending of the Papua New Guinea Government. It instanced extravagance on overseas visits, the ministerial fleet of cars and a new executive jet. In commenting on the 19 provisional governments the bank observed that they devoted too large a portion of income to merely governing and too little to providing services to the people .

This is a very serious criticism of part of our aid program. What I am trying to get through to the Minister-the Minister knows that I have raised this matter many times before-is that the very basis of the program that is coming out in this Bill, which is to have a more informed and a more enlightened approach to project aid, is the type of program we should be developing for Papua New Guinea . I believe the continuation of Australian aid in the form of budget support-we are talking about a very sizable amount of money, $254m -has encouraged extravagant expenditure which, as I pointed out from the Bank of Papua New Guinea report, has not resulted in the desired benefits going to the bulk of the Australian people. It is just lumped into recurrent expenditure in a budget. There is no identification of Australian aid and no evaluation. This covers 45 per cent of Australia's total aid program.

This is not something we have thought up just recently. In April 1973, when I still had the responsibilities for Papua New Guinea on behalf of this Parliament , I pointed out that what we should have been developing was a program of project aid and that we should be moving away from the form of budget supplementation. Exactly six years later the report on the Third World echoed precisely those views then stated. Page 189 of the report on the Third World states:
. . . Australia should give progressively less emphasis in its overall program to aid for general budget support and more to project-type aid.
Dealing specifically with Papua New Guinea, the Committee neatly paraphrased the views that I had expressed back in 1973, in these words:

The proportion of the annual aid budget directed at Papua New Guinea should continue to be reduced as quickly as practicable. The budget support grant component should be complemented by project aid and technical assistance, so as to place Papua New Guinea on a less dissimilar footing to that of other recipients.

Unfortunately, the Government has not sought to implement the recommendations of that report, but I rather hope that when programs such as are envisaged in the legislation before us are fully implemented, there will be a basis upon which Australia can develop a bilateral project relationship with Papua New Guinea, so that the Australian taxpayer, and after all the $254m comes from him, will feel more confident that the money that he is required to pay to the Government is being used in projects that are identifiable, that can be evaluated and, in fact , can be seen to make a contribution to the aid program. I do not believe that the present form in which aid is given to Papua New Guinea does that. I do not think that it enables the Australian taxpayer to see that effective use is made of the money that he makes available to the Government. Nor do I believe that it plays an effective part in the welfare of the people of Papua New Guinea.

Perhaps this Bill is the swallow that will make the summer. I hope that the thinking behind it, the reasons for its presentation, will also be reasons that may well lie behind a recasting of our aid program to Papua New Guinea-a recasting that will move it away from what I regard as being a highly inefficient Budget support program to a project aid type of program tailored to meet the needs of the people of Papua New Guinea.

We commend the Bill to the House. We see some difficulties, in the details that have already been made available to us concerning the administrative structure, particularly as to how the Centre will operate, but we commend the Government for the implementation of the recommendation of the Third World report that was issued back in 1979. We will introduce the amendments concerning the timing for the sunset provisions at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: .-Very briefly, I would like to say something along the lines of what the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) has just said and make a few additional points.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition welcomes this Bill, albeit with one or two small reservations, in the hope that it is an indication of things to come in government policy on the food aid question and on the co-ordination of Australian overseas aid.

Having just returned from a Labor Party and parliamentary delegation to the Middle East, for me two things stood out from our time there which are of direct relevance to this Bill. The first was how immensely valuable Australian agricultural techniques and experience are in the whole Middle East. The second was how much Australia's own programs of agricultural research and assistance in the Middle East, and in Middle East-related studies here, are in need of central co-ordination, in which the proposed Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research should assist, but in respect of which it will not prove sufficient.

When we were in Iraq we took the opportunity to visit two Australian projects, one near the town of Mosul and the other close to the Kurdish area of Iraq in Arbil. The project near Mosul is operated by the West Australian Government's Department of Agriculture. The other is operated by the South Australian Government's Department of Agriculture. I understand that similar projects, again under State government auspices, operate in Jordan, Libya and the Sudan.

It would be wrong of me to fail to mention what an excellent image of Australia the participants in these projects convey. They are accommodating and courageous people who are sensitive to local feelings and needs and they operate in some degree of danger. The Iraqi Government was imensely impressed by the fact that when the war with Iran broke out, unlike a large number of aid personnel from other countries who immediately left, the Australians stayed behind and were prepared to tough it out. The people in the project described for me how they watched the Iranian bombers fly overhead. In fact, their farm became a focal point for the personnel on a number of other projects who were being pulled back from border areas. They all congregated in the West Australian project area. The South Australian project continues to operate in a situation of some danger. In fact, recently, several personnel from the project immediately adjacent, which is run by the Australians, were kidnapped, held by Kurdish rebels for a few months and have only just been released. That was a cause of some nervousness at the Australian project, but was not sufficient cause for them to quit their activities. I understand that, to a considerable degree, they are satisfied with the security that is provided by the Iraqi Government. Nevertheless, they can never be entirely certain and therefore deserve praise for staying on.

Basically, the projects are establishing examples of effective crop rotation, using legumes, which are also helpful in animal husbandry. The land on which the project in Iraq is being developed is among the oldest agricultural land in the world. In fact, it is probably the first area in which wheat was grown. The land is very good; it is just over-utilised. The quality of the land in the Middle East varies widely but it is all of a type that is within the experience of Australian farmers and agricultural scientists and therefore likely to be the subject of considerable interest to the institute that is to be established under this legislation-a fact of which a large number of Middle Eastern states are now becoming very aware.

These states are now taking an interest in what Australia and Australian research institutions have to offer. In their case, it is not a question of aid. They are prepared and able to pay for the advice that they need, but it is useful to contemplate, as we consider this Bill, some of the political and economic considerations that underpin the interest of some of the under- developed countries in the Middle East in the type of research that this new institute will co-ordinate. In their interest, it contains some positive aspects . Also, in their interest, it contains some dangers to be avoided.

There is throughout the Middle East an obsession with food security, defined as self-sufficiency. This is producing policies which one might well argue are irrational and ought not to be encouraged. When we were in Saudi Arabia, for example, we were informed by the Minister for Agriculture that they were currently subsidising wheat production, in order to achieve self-sufficiency, at five times the average world price. It would be far more sensible for the Saudis , for example, to spend that money in upgrading the capacity of the Sudanese to produce precisely the same sorts of crops. But such is the concern about food security that even in an area where there has been a certain amount of co- ordinated activity to this point, in many cases countries are reluctant to engage in rational distribution or specialisation.

However, it is the politics of food which is causing this type of decision to be made. It was interesting to note, when we interviewed him, the views of Dr Abdul Rahman al Sheikh, the Saudi Arabian Minister for Agriculture, on the question of the recent grain embargo on the Soviet Union. The Saudis are not well known for their love of the Soviet Union or their appreciation of Soviet foreign policy. However, he argued for Saudi self-sufficiency for a number of reasons. An important one was that countries should not permit themselves to be the object of political blackmail by being deficient in an essential item. He was not himself condemning the notion that one ought to use food politically. I do not think that anyone who had participated in an oil embargo would consider that he had the right to do that. However, he noted the point and having noted it, the lesson he drew from it was that Saudi Arabia needed to establish self- sufficiency. That is a calculation that we ought not to encourage, but it has been associated with the type of discussion which has led to the establishment of research institutes such as this internationally. This stemmed directly from the circumstances in which the food issue was brought onto the international agenda in 1974.

Whereas in 1971 the international community had established the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research, it was an initiative by Henry Kissinger, in particular, in 1974 which provoked the sustained interest of the international community in the food question.

Henry Kissinger is a complex man. In his counter attack on the philosophy and policy behind the 1973-74 oil embargo he initiated through the United States Administration of the time a world food conference which met in Rome for the first time in November 1974. In the course of his speech to the conference he made clear the increasing vulnerability of the Third World to the vagaries of the major food producers. He emphasised how necessary it was that the world producers and consumers look at this matter collectively and out of the context of the seizing of unilateral advantage. He was arguing the same point on oil production in another forum.

His speech was seen by the Arabs as partly menacing and partly a genuine effort to deal with the growing problem. At that conference, Kissinger quoted an Egyptian official of the conference, Sayed A. Marai, to establish the extent of the feed production problem of the developing countries. He estimated that the then rate of growth in production of 2 1/2 per cent per annum would leave a gap by 1985 of 85 million tons in Third World production as opposed to Third World needs from a situation where the gap was 25 million tons in 1974. The gap was right on target. It is now over 60 million tons despite resolutions of that 1974 conference to undertake programs of research and development for the Third World that would ensure growth rates, it was hoped, of 4 per cent per annum. The most serious situation is in Africa where about 10 per cent less food is produced per person now than there was at that time. The problem is also general, and it is a problem that the food research institute is supposed to deal with. The point is that, despite the recognition of the problem and recognition of the need to improve production in the Third World and distribution from the producers, very little has been achieved.

I mentioned recognition of potential production of the Third World. Probably about a 30 per cent expansion of productive land in the Third World is possible, and greatly increased output from land now under production is also possible. The political impediments to this in the Third World are immense and it is beyond our capacity and the capacity of the research institute to do anything. The technical impediments, however, are something which, I hope, we can overcome , and this legislation will, to some degree, assist.

At the outset I referred to the Middle East, as opposed to the whole Third World, and I shall now return to that aspect. There are states in the Middle East which can buy all the technical expertise we have, and then some. They have already offered large sums of money for Australian research and are quickly off the mark in using Australian expertise on the spot. Libya has been a case in point on both counts. I understand several universities have dovetailed already several research projects on the basis of Libyan Government initiatives or Libyan programs. These are not projects which should be spurned but they create two important problems that this Government and this research institute will need to think about particularly as the institute will be capable of receiving private funds as well as government funds.

The first problem is whether, in reality, our technical advice will go to those who can pay for it. I know this is not the Government's intention but in financially straitened circumstances the temptation will be strong. The second and related point is that included in an assessment of upon whose behalf the research is to be done and assistance provided consideration must be given to reinforcing areas of possible success and not simply suiting the whims of those who can pay. If presented with a choice based on financial stringencies or limited physical resources, it would be better, for example, to aid Sudan's wheat production rather than to assist Saudi Arabia's program for the development of wheat self-sufficiency in that country.

The second point I made earlier was that our experience in the Middle East suggested that Australia very much needed central co-ordination in its food research and assistance program. The Government really has been very slow off the mark with this institute. The need for such institutes was agreed upon by the international community in 1971. By 1974 eight such institutes were in existence. We have had a minor involvement with a number of these and subsequently established ones. The result has been an ad hoc involvement by State governments without any sense of priority in the projects of the type I have discussed. Good things have been done by them that deserve repetition in areas of even greater need but the resources of the State governments will not run to projects in countries that cannot pay for them. Therefore, it is to be hoped that this institute will help to alleviate some of these problems of co- ordination. It cannot do it alone, however; it must be an act of deliberate government policy.

Overall there needs to be a much more systematic analysis in this country of our international role as a major food supplier and exporter of food production expertise. There is some evidence from this proposal and the higher priority assigned food security issues in our aid programs in the last Budget that this has now been recognised. However, there is no indication that our capacities have been thoroughly integrated into our foreign policy. Part of our immaturity as a nation has been that we rarely sit down and analyse the international system from first principles. When we consider the indices of power for example we look at a military-strategic balance between the super-powers and judge our value by the contribution we make to that balance in its own narrowly defined terms.

We ignore, through ignorance, the significance of matters such as food exports and expertise. These are considered domestically in discussions of the balance of trade and payments and internationally in terms of the good things we do for others. Were we to properly analyse the indices of power in the international community we would recognise that not just oil but also food is a universally vital commodity in the hands of a few producers. This was quite evident during the oil boycott in 1973 when we were not a boycotted nation, and that was a decision on the part of the oil producers not unrelated to the fact that we were providing about 30 per cent of Egypt's food at the time. Others expect us to be consciously thinking about these issues, and this certainly was the case among the Arabs that we met. The real impact of our commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force, for example, on Arab opinion and policy is not, as some fear , the possibilities of Arab trade boycotts of us but rather another plank in the platform of Arab suspicions of the West and consequent effects on the Arab assessment of the reliability of Australia as a supplier.

It is quite evident that American policy on the issue of food and politics is such that reliance on American supplies is not compatible with the Arab sense of full national sovereignty. The more we are connected with United States policy on food boycotts and its policy generally, the more those suspicions are likely to be transferred to us. We should be aware that co-operation for food security is one of the main activities of the newly formed Gulf Co-operation Council, a council which the West has generally welcomed because of the security purposes it serves in co-ordinating a conservative Arab State Gulf response to possible radical activities in the Gulf area. It is interested also in food security and it is not worried about imports from the Soviet Union; it is worried about imports from the West.

That is why it is now absolutely essential that Australia comes to clear conclusions about how it intends to use its food production politically. Do we intend to be a reliable supplier in all circumstances except those in which an important importing country takes direct action to damage us, or are we to flirt with the political possibilities of food boycotts on a more ad hoc or intangible basis? If we choose the latter, we must be prepared to face the prospects of increasingly irrational decisions by Third World countries and other consumers as they attempt to evade the consequences of such actions. However, if we choose either course we must be prepared to sit down and work out coherent positions on questions of distribution and production of the food surplus nations and the possibilities for improved production in the Third World. I very much hope that this move by the Government will be a step in that direction, that it will be followed by an appropriate analysis by the Government of where exactly we stand as a result of our food production in the international community and that appropriate policies will be developed accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating issues related to a new term in international jargon-North-South issues. We are talking about the haves and the have nots and the way in which the needs of the lesser developed countries can be met and assisted by more developed countries. I refer to a statement issued from the Cancun Summit by the co-chairman, which said that they believed that the focus on relationships between North and South, particularly the serious economic problems confronting the international community, had been seen as one of the most serious challenges to be faced by the coming decade, ranking and linked with the maintenance of world peace as a priority for the attention of all governments. The upgrading and support of lesser developed countries in Asia, Africa, South America and the smaller island states is of significant importance to the whole world.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring to the attention of the House the progress of thought in North-South relations and particularly the initiatives taken by the Brandt Commission, followed by the Harries report on Australia's relations with the Third World and dealt with here in Australia during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting and later by the 22 heads of government meeting at Cancun. In fact the result of that process has been to change completely world attitudes, particularly the attitudes of the free world. It is an unfortunate fact of life that the Soviet Union does not get involved in any way in aid programs or support for less developed countries. The changes that were brought about I think were, first of all, an identification by the Brandt Commission of the real issues affecting the lesser developed countries. These were further refined at the meeting of 44 Commonwealth heads and leaders meeting in Melbourne. That meeting, in fact, was able to express in a most useful and forceful way those factors which were later pursued at Cancun. Leaders as diverse in outlook as Maurice Bishop and Miss Eugenia Charles, Mrs Gandhi and Mrs Thatcher presented views arising from a common and shared concern for the well being of lesser developed countries. In passing, I pay tribute-in mentioning these factors-to the work done at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), who is at the table, and by the Australian Government in identifying the real areas of concern.

Certainly, the factors that really were identified by lesser developed countries were related, as other honourable members have mentioned, to food stocks and security of supply. But also identified were matters concerning trade areas-tariff and non tariff protection-agro industries and the development and further refinement of produce of basic agricultural industries, the programs of aid and support which have been the traditional approach for giving support to lesser developed countries, the processes of identifying and developing alternative energy resources, the conservation of energy in energy-scarce countries or countries that have not the wealth or capacity to purchase oil or gas. Other areas identified related to the development of tourism, the problems of the law of the sea and the problems of small island states in connection with the law of the sea, the development of trade arrangements with developed countries in those areas where developed countries do not supply certain goods themselves, protection against natural disaster and, of course, debt restructuring. In fact, all of these issues impinge more or less on the internal capacity of countries to produce food, further refine it and then export it.
I will quote briefly again from the report of the summit at Cancun where the leaders of the 22 countries agreed:
Persistent and widespread manifestations of hunger are entirely incompatible with the level of development attained by the world economy.
The report mentioned also that the need for:

Sustained and long-term internal effort on the part of the developing countries to attain increasing self-sufficiency in food production is the basic element in obtaining a real answer to the problem of hunger.

It made further suggestions, pointed to programs geared to eradicate hunger by the year 2000 and task forces to identify further the needs of developing countries. I think the work at Cancun whilst wide and sweeping and done in a formal sense really reinforces the work traditionally carried out by the Commonwealth. Some people regard the Commonwealth as a decrepit and old institution. In fact, the work done under existing Commonwealth activities in agriculture and food security is substantial and covers a wide spectrum of countries. In fact, that program deals, in part, with the transfer and promotion of rural technologies, reduction of post harvest losses, preparation of agricultural projects for international funding, training of agricultural project managers and extension workers, management of irrigation projects and the development of livestock and fishery programs.

Australia has been a willing and active participant exercising a great deal of expertise and input in all of these areas of concern. Australia has a unique capacity for the practical expression of aid and assistance. This is due to our expertise in agricultural production particularly in crop and animal management but also in agro industries. Whether it be in the development of root crops, new cash crops or fruit crops in island States or whether it be in arid farming techniques and the breeding of new wheat varieties of crops for central Africa, I think the expertise that Australia has has been very cleverly and carefully identified by the Government as being the major contribution that we can make to lesser developed countries.

I am delighted by the decision to establish an institute of this type drawing on the innate qualities, skills and expertise of Australians. I think we should be proud that we are going to establish a centre for a loose but sophisticated and skilled group of people to consult, confirm and draw on the expertise of lesser developing countries, identifying with their assistance programs to advance their food production and food security. I will conclude my remarks at this point but I would be remiss if I did not refer again to the work and initiatives taken by the Australian Government and particularly the work of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments proposed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) relate, as he said, to the sunset provisions described in clauses 43 and 44 of the Bill. As far as I am aware, the only other piece of Australian legislation which has such a provision is the Human Rights Commission Act of 1981, which contains a section along similar lines. The Government is not prepared to accept these amendments, but it is not rejecting them merely because they have been moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions in the legislation relating to the term of office of the Director, the timing of the review and the expiration of the legislation at seven, 10 and 12 years respectively have been decided upon only after the most careful consideration. I would like to explain the reasons for these three periods in turn. After seeking expert advice, the Government considered the initial term of up to seven years as the most appropriate for two reasons. Firstly, reasonable tenure was considered to be essential to attract the very best people in the field to the position. Secondly, it will provide the first Director with sufficient time to establish the Centre and to have it in full operation, bearing in mind the long lead times involved in agricultural research , before his appointment expires. If there is a change of Director after seven years the next critical date is that relating to the review process, which under the legislation would be 10 years. This has been very deliberately chosen to give a new Director three years to make his mark on the organisation and to implement new policies before the review is undertaken. There would then be two years in which to conduct the review and, depending on the result, adequate time to prepare new legislation or, if the review came to the conclusion that the legislation should not be renewed, adequate time to wind down the activities of the Centre.

It will be seen that all the periods chosen by the Government form part of a carefully related and integrated package. If, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is proposing in his amendment, the legislation runs for a period of eight years with a review after the sixth year, the Government believes strongly that the ability of the Centre to achieve the objectives as laid down in this legislation would be seriously impaired and that it would be difficult to attract a Director of the highest calibre. Under the timetable proposed by the Opposition's amendment, a Director appointed for seven years would find himself in the position of having his administration reviewed when nearing the end of his appointment. This in itself would not be too great a problem, but in conjunction with the proposed sunset period of eight years could lead to a ridiculous situation. The review itself would take some time, perhaps a year, and an incoming Director could be faced, depending on the recommendations of the review, with major changes to the operation of the Centre immediately after taking up his position or even closure during what could be his single year of office.

There is a further point in relation to this which must be taken into account to ensure the effective operation of the Centre. That is, agricultural research by its very nature is long term and in most cases one is looking at a lead time of 3 or 4 years from the commencement of a research project until results are obtained which can be translated into practical field action. The timetable proposed by the Opposition ignores this very important consideration. On the other hand the legislation as drafted has been specifically designed with this aspect very much in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The observations made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) underline the advantages associated with the eight- year period. As the Minister pointed out, under the legislation the Director is to be appointed for seven years. He would therefore hold office during the period of the review and before another Director was appointed. I think the purpose of having sunset provisions-certainly this is the case in respect of sunset provisions which apply in the United States of America-is to ensure that organisations which are set up do not perpetuate themselves, do not develop their own dynamic. I think it is important that the first review of any organisation be undertaken reasonably early-taking on board the views expressed by the Minister that such a review should not take place too early-so that the rationale for having the organisation can be effectively assessed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that a perceived period of 12 years is a very long lifetime for any organisation. It may well be that after the first review subsequent sunset provisions could be written in for a longer dateline. But there are some difficulties, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) pointed out, in respect of administration which might appear to be quite unresolvable. We certainly would know the position at the end of six years. Therefore, I think that in placing a sunset provision in the legislation-as the Minister pointed out, this is only the second piece of Federal legislation into which such a provision has been introduced-we should not set a time scale too far into the future for making an assessment of how effective the organisation is going to be .

This legislation seeks to establish an experimental Centre. The program of the Centre has to be worked out. The Director who has set up and progressed with the organisation will be appointed for seven years. It seems to me that it would be appropriate for a review to take place while the original Director is still with the organisation. Our proposition still stands. This is, in terms of Australian legislation, experimental. I do not think we should put back the assessment of that experimentation for 12 years. It seems to me that the proposition that has been put forward by the Opposition is eminently sensible, particularly as it is only the second piece of sunset legislation in Australia and it applies to an organisation that will be very malleable in terms of implementation of the sunset provisions.

I would like to reiterate a point which I think is important. This Parliament, which is responsible for the passage of legislation, should also have some input and participate in some way in the assessment of the effectiveness of organisations that its legislation establishes. I hope the Minister will take on board the fact that this Parliament has a role to play, that the Parliament in enacting legislation should be able to be in a position to review the effectiveness of that legislation. This has always been a great difficulty for this Parliament. It is not so much a difficulty in the United States where sunset provisions have been operating since 1975. But it seems to me that if the Parliament is to play an effective role it should be in a position to review the effectiveness of the legislation that it passes. Despite the views that have been put forward by the Minister, we believe in the first instance that the time scale we have suggested for a review to be undertaken after six years and for the Centre to be disbanded after eight years if the legislation is not renewed is much more preferable to the longer time scale that the Government has suggested in the legislation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Alice Springs: Commercial Television Service-Industrial Relations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Alice Springs: Commercial Television Service-Industrial Relations
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Today I presented a petition relating to the provision of a commercial television licence in Alice Springs. I was pleased to receive the petition and to present it in this place. It represents hard work and efforts by a number of Alice Springs residents. The issue is topical in Alice Springs and has won widespread support in the community of central Australia. It has been widely covered in the media. To give some idea of local priority, a third of the entire population of Alice Springs signed the petition. Over 6,200 signatures were obtained. This was achieved largely through the work of one concerned citizen, Bob Freeman, whom I congratulate on his successful campaign. The petition was collected in four weeks between 11 November and 4 December 1981 with an estimated 90 hours of canvassing. To understand the enthusiasm and impetus engendered on this matter I would point out that at the end of the first week 3,000 signatures had been collected; by the end of the second week, 4,750; by the end of the third week, 5,750; and by the fourth week, 6,200.

SPEECH.PARA: Alice Springs is growing rapidly. It is the second largest town in the Northern Territory. A significant component of the local economy is tourism and tourists also have a keen interest in television when on holidays. I point out that the estimated population growth for Alice Springs this year is over 4 per cent. Currently the Australian Broadcasting Commission is servicing Alice Springs via the national service. There is no local content in Alice Springs programming. The news is from Darwin or interstate. The local news is only a five-minute segment voice service with the ABC logo on the screen. The ABC has given good service to Alice Springs and to the whole of the Northern Territory but commercial television will mean a choice in programs, increased local component in television programs and better sports coverage. We are seeing the expansion of services to more remote communities. However, in larger towns there is room for more local variety.

Alice Springs residents want commercial television which is demonstrated by the 6,200 signatures to this petition. Commercial television does not have to be huge. In fact, it would not be economically viable if it were on a capital city scale but the success of commercial television stations in smaller centres and in remote areas has already been demonstrated as has been shown by NTD Channel 8 in Darwin. The time arises when regional centres develop and can sustain commercial television services. The Government should encourage establishment of commercial broadcasters especially where commercial interests are servicing remote communities and complementing ABC services. I am aware of interest by several media groups in obtaining a commercial television licence. However, there are problems in the processing of applications at the moment. I understand that the Department of Communications has 700 applications before it and that under the present system it will take between 15 to 20 years to process them. That is a hopeless situation. I have been advised that the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) has ordered a reorganisation of the procedure, to simplify the bureaucratic procedure and to expedite processing so that this time span can be drastically reduced to meet the needs of new television audiences. I commend the Minister for his action and express the hope that the administrative details for new procedures will soon be finalised. Alice Springs interests must be catered for so that the Alice Springs residents can get commercial television before the end of the year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What chemicals were involved in the Weed Control Training Program conducted by the Agricultural Protection Board of Western Australia as part of the Flora and Fauna Conservation Training Program funded by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs?
(2) Was the chemical 2,4,5-T mixed with diesel oil, used as part of the program ?
(3) If so, is this considered a safe mixture for such a labour-intensive weed control program?
(4) What was involved specifically in the training of these Aboriginal people in techniques of safe handling of such chemicals?
(5) Was protective clothing provided for the trainees, if so, was it utilised?
(6) Have any trainees' health problems been brought to the attention of the Minister?
(7) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that at least 6 of the Aboriginal trainees involved in the use of these chemicals have experienced severe forms of dermatitis?
(8) If so, is the Minister able to say haw many of these Aboriginal trainees have received medical attention for the dermatitis that has resulted from the use of these chemicals?

(9) Is it a fact that in at least 2 instances the skin disorder has involved severe burns and scalding resulting in at least one instance skin grafts being required and another instance of recurrent peeling of facial tissue?

(10) What steps has the Minister taken to ensure that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, which is funding this training program, will now take action to ensure comprehensive medical assessment of the trainees who were involved in this use of 2,4,5-T, also known as Agent Orange?
(11) Will the Minister ensure that the Department arranges to initiate any necessary health care programs for the victims of this chemical training program ?
(12) Will the Minister also ensure that the Department assists the individuals involved in any necessary legal action for compensation or damages?
(13) Is it possible that the skin damage was caused by the diesel oil or kerosene carrier and not by the chemical component?

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my interim reply of 15 October 1981, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has now received the following advice from the Western Australian authorities:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) and (2) The Agricultural Protection Board (APB) has sprayed Noogoora Burr with 2,4,-D and water only; some trainees have used 2,4,5-T and diesel when spraying Parkinsonia.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Agricultural Protection Board carries out training under the supervision of expert operators with assistance from the occupational Health Branch of the Public Health Department of Western Australia.
(5) The use of protective clothing is advised and it is provided by the APB.

(6), (7), (8) and (9) Three trainees received workers compensation for medical treatment for skin complaints during their work on Noogoora Burr control. There is no evidence to link the skin complaints with the use of chemicals.

(10) and (11) 2,4,5-T is not known as Agent Orange. Air and urine tests have been carried out on APB employees to monitor exposure to both 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T and have indicated no danger to health. Monitoring of occupational exposure will continue. No other special health care program is indicated.

(12) Legal assistance is available to Aboriginals through the Aboriginal Legal Service, which is funded by my Department, should any Aboriginals consider that they have a claim for compensation on the State in respect of skin complaints.
(13) Yes, but the cases of dermatitis referred to were reported to be caused by Noogoora Burr and not diesel, kerosene or the chemical component. This was the medical opinion.
